description:
Chloe's Revenge, Written and performed by Chloe Bettina.
Part love letter, part exposé, Chloe’s Revenge is a musical theatre-inspired show that pulls back the curtain on the pro-am musical theatre “industry” in Aotearoa. With biting wit, Chloe lays bare the heartbreak of rejection from the world she adores, and turns that pain into power. This is a story of survival, self-discovery, and the ultimate comeback: becoming the best version of yourself when the system says you don’t belong. You don't have to be a "musical theatre person" to enjoy this show. In fact, it's better if you're not.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Over and Out @ TAHI Festival, "NEVER become a truck driver!" - A young Jackson Burling took that advice, avoiding the fork in the road, but now, after a long and gruelling two year slog in the arts industry he must confront that age old question: "why not, Dad?" - and take us along for the ride.
In ‘Over and Out’, premiering at the 2025 TAHI Festival, he’ll bring you a REAL interview, a BIG character, and even bigger QUESTIONS to the stage. One actor. 50 minutes. Countless emotional potholes
Along the way, we get a rare look into the gritty, heartfelt, and often-overlooked life of one of Aotearoa’s essential workers — the truck driver
Is the open road calling — or is the stage his true destination?
Buckle up. This is verbatim theatre with serious mileage.
Created and Performed by Jackson Burling
Directed by Simon Leary | Produced by Tom Smith

description:
Kiwis Big Hararei, Written by Catriona Tipene & Ryan Cundy
Produced by Horse With No Name with GRIDLEY by Victoria
Directed by Catriona Tipene
From the Land of the Long White Cloud to the Land Down Under!
Kiwi is going on his first big holiday from Aotearoa across to the golden shores of Brisbane. He’s got his backpack, a pocket full of worms, and a head full of dreams. The most exciting thing of all is that he might even get to go on a rollercoaster! With his Mum, Kiwi navigates air travel, hotels and conversations with marsupials as his world stretches from the home he knows, to the world over the horizon.
A tale that celebrates the connection between our two countries, featuring stunning costume designs by GRIDLEY by Victoria and fresh waiata by NZ singer-songwriter Benny Tipene. Brought to the stage by the multi-award winning companies Horse With No Name and GRIDLEY by Victoria, Kiwi’s Big Hararei is a story about spreading your wings and flying into the unknown.

Acclaim for Trees, Bees and Me (2024):
“I don’t even know where to start in telling you how absolutely captivating, magical and real this show is.” Tania Du Toit, Regional News
“every costume adds such a beautiful connection between the characters while the colours each beautifully blend so well together.” Brie Keatley, Art Murmurs
Acclaim for Land of the Long Long Drive (2023):
“Horse With No Name have come up with one of the best children’s theatre shows that Wellington has seen in quite some time.” Deborah Rea, Theatreview

description:
Art and AI: Brit Bunkley in Conversation with Megan Dunn, Artist and filmmaker Brit Bunkley discusses the pragmatics and politics of making art with AI. Join us for a discussion in the Gallery, with insights into the making of his latest work Archive, commissioned for Messengers.
--
Brit Bunkley is a New Zealand-based artist and videographer whose practice spans sculpture, installation, and digital media. A recipient of the US National Endowment for the Arts fellowship, two NY state grants, and the Rome Prize Fellowship, his work explores the intersection of physical and virtual spaces, often blending surreal imagery with themes of history, politics, and environmental concerns. He has exhibited at the Museum of New Zealand Te Papa and internationally at Rencontres Internationales Paris/Berlin, FILE São Paulo (including 2025), and the Athens Digital Arts Festival. Recent exhibitions include Visions in the Nunnery, London (2022), Cybersculpture 2024 at Collège des Bernardins, Paris, and The Torrance Art Museum, LA (2025). In 2024, he won Best Art | Experimental Video/Film at the New York City Independent Film Festival. His work continues to evolve, embracing new technologies and alternative methodologies to challenge perceptions of reality and imagination.
label: Business & Networking

description:
August's Nomadic Speaker: Rachel Young, Rachel Young is a freelance graphic designer, traveller, and occasional van-dweller who’s spent the last few years navigating the messy, beautiful reality of creative nomad life.
For Rachel, being a ‘nomad’ has never been just about travel, but a mindset. Since leaving her home in the UK in 2019, she’s moved across the world, worked remotely from a van, taught graphic design in China, and rebuilt her creative career more than once.
Today, she blends her love of design with a passion for helping other creatives navigate the highs, lows, and mindset shifts of freelance life, while inspiring those around her to pursue their own dreams.
In this Friday's talk, she shares the unfiltered truths of freelancing on the move - from creative burnout to financial uncertainty - along with the mindset tools that can make the journey not just survivable, but meaningful and joyful.

Learn the processes required to boost your cash levels

description:
Treasury Guest Lecture with Michael Keen: IN-PERSON attendance, Join us for our special Fiscal Policy for the Future seminar
New Zealand faces significant long-term fiscal challenges, including the rising costs associated with an ageing population, increasing demand for public services, and the need to adapt to a changing global economy. These pressures will require careful planning to ensure the sustainability of government finances while maintaining fairness and efficiency in the tax system.
Inland Revenue’s draft Long-Term Insights Briefing explores these issues by asking critical questions about the future shape and scale of our tax system. Similarly, the Treasury’s Long-Term Fiscal Statement highlights the importance of future-proofing our tax framework and other broader policy settings to address these challenges.
Join us for this seminar delivered by a highly regarded economist and expert in tax policy and administration, and a prolific author, Michael Keen, as he shares his insights on future proofing our tax system.
This will be a hybrid event, and we encourage you to attend it in person for an opportunity to engage in a discussion on all those issues with our guest speaker.
About this event
This will be a hybrid event. Please use this site to register if you plan to attend it in person.
If you would like to attend it virtually, please use THIS LINK to register.
The Tax Policy Charitable Trust has arranged Mick’s visit to New Zealand. The Trust was established to support leading tax policy thinking in New Zealand. You can read about the Trust’s work here.
About the presenter
Michael (Mick) Keen is a former Deputy Director of the Fiscal Affairs Department at the International Monetary Fund, where for over twenty years he played a central role in shaping and delivering IMF policies and advice on tax matters.
He has advised finance ministries in all parts of the world, including missions to over forty countries, and led the preparation of influential papers for the G20 and the Executive Board of the IMF.
Before joining the Fund, Mick was Professor of Economics at the universities of Essex (UK), Queens (Canada) and Kyoto, and is now Ushioda Fellow at the University of Tokyo.
Mick was the keynote speaker at the 2014 conference on the Future of Tax Administration in New Zealand and has provided peer review for Inland Revenue’s previous Long-Term Insights Briefing.
Mick has jointly authored, with Joel Slemrod, Rebellion, Rascals and Revenue – an entertaining account of how history illuminates the perennial challenges and timeless principles of taxation—and how the past holds clues to solving the tax problems of today.
About this seminar series
New ideas, innovative concepts, research evidence and expert advice are all crucial to stimulate and inform the Treasury’s economic analysis and advice. Our current theme for guest lectures - Fiscal Policy for the Future - explores the role of stabilising, sustainable and effective fiscal policy. Speakers provide insights into how fiscal policy can be designed to support government to meet its current and future objectives and obligations while adapting to changing circumstances and delivering value to the New Zealand public.
Fiscal policy has a stabilising role in helping to smooth the business cycle, while sustainability in fiscal policy is foundational for resilience to both shocks and longstanding challenges, such as climate change, technological advancements, and demographic trends. Ensuring effective and value for money expenditure is important so that fiscal policy contributes to the living standards of New Zealanders, both now and in the future.
Please note that the views, opinions, findings, and conclusions expressed in the Treasury Guest Lecture Series are those of the individual presenters. They do not necessarily reflect the views of the New Zealand Treasury or the New Zealand Government.
For updates and our latest research visit: www.treasury.govt.nz
Keep in touch
If you would like to be the first to hear about our upcoming events in the Treasury Guest Lecture Series, please SUBSCRIBE to stay up to date.

Managing for value: building a strong financial advice business-Wellington, Building a valuable financial advice business means you have a resilient business to support your clients and a strong asset. Transactions – acquisition and disposal support the long-term growth and sustainability of financial advice provider businesses. Transactions take many forms, going concerns regularly acquire and dispose of clients, business units, lines of business, have investors buy-in, bring key staff together – and split businesses up. Only a small number of our transactions are the classic market exit.
Our aim is to spend time talking with advisers about how to grow their business and manage for value – making their business more valuable by explicitly thinking about valuation in addition to the other metrics such as profit and cashflow.

description:
Impactful Leadership, Impactful Leadership:
What do horses, mules and the All Blacks have in common? Hear a true expert break-down what really works when it comes to impactful leadership.
Welcome to the final conversation in our Women in Business series: four events that bring you important conversations led by Women in Business and heard by everyone. In partnership with Forsyth Barr, this bar-setting series is bringing hard-hitting topics into the conversational spotlight.
What good leadership looks like has changed, but many of the methods we rely on to deliver it haven’t. This conversation will showcase what horses can teach us about impactful leadership in modern workplaces, and how anyone can turn those lessons into action that delivers.
Why be part of this conversation?
In this thought-provoking session, BBC journalist-turned-leadership coach Janine Sudbury will share how she discovered what really works in leadership development, and why traditional approaches often fall short.
You’ll take away insights including:
The three secrets of the horse whisperer that unlock authentic, presence-based leadership
How to overcome Imposter Syndrome and People Pleasing to lead with clarity and confidence
Why horses give the most honest feedback—and how that feedback creates lasting breakthroughs
Who’s the speaker?
Janine Sudbury is the founder of Impact Leadership and the creator of a truly unique experiential leadership programme that swaps the boardroom for the paddock. specialises in helping women overcome Imposter Syndrome and People Pleasing Syndrome to lead with more confidence, clarity, and authenticity.
With powerful insights and unforgettable stories, including her work with former All Blacks coach Steve Hansen, Janine invites you to lead with more purpose, presence, and impact.

About this event:

Effective governance reporting is essential for successful project, programme, and portfolio delivery. Join us for an exclusive webinar where two industry experts—each representing leading software tools—will share insights on how to optimize reporting processes, enhance decision-making, and track progress with precision.

This session will explore critical elements of governance reporting, including the dashboards and key information decision makers need to ensure transparency and accountability. Our speakers will showcase best practices for structuring reports, selecting the right performance indicators, and using real-time data to drive strategic outcomes. Learn how to streamline reporting workflows, reduce manual effort, and leverage technology to provide stakeholders with clear, actionable insights.

Whether you're managing a single project, a programme, an entire portfolio, PMO, or a member of any delivery governance committee, this webinar will equip you with practical strategies and the right tools to improve oversight and control. Gain valuable knowledge from experts in project governance and software solutions that support effective reporting.
About the Presenter:
About the Presenters:

Youssef Mourra is the founder, Director, and Principal Consultant at Nonsuch. He delivers consulting across all the layers of Project, Programme and Portfolio Management (P3M) in organisations of any size and type. He is known for developing practical and pragmatic solutions that help organisations achieve their desired business outcomes and to execute their strategies.

Bruce Aylward is the "Chief Everything Officer" of Psoda, isn't your average tech CEO. His journey took him from the starry skies of rocket science to revolutionizing cloud-based project management software.

Poroporoaki for Rosalie & Welcome to Elizabeth & Shaquille, Kia ora e te whānau EHF,
You're invited to a very special evening!
Join us on Wednesday 27 August at 5:30pm for a heart-filled poroporoaki, a chance to celebrate Rosalie Nelson, and to officially welcome our new Co-Executive Directors, Elizabeth McNaughton and Shaquille Shortland.
📍 Te Wharewaka Function Centre, Wellington
🕔 Doors open at 5:00pm | Welcome begins at 5:30pm sharp
🕢 Event concludes by 7:30pm
👔 Dress: Business casual
To RSVP (button)
To register to join online (button)
This will be a joyful evening of reflection, reconnection and looking ahead. Whether you're joining us in person or online, we’d love to have you in the room (or on the screen!) as we mark this milestone in the life of the Fellowship. You are also welcome to bring your partner.
In te ao Māori, a poroporoaki is more than a farewell; it's a ritual of transition and gratitude. A moment to steady the waka, acknowledge the hands that have guided it, and prepare together for the voyage ahead.
We’ll honour Rosalie’s contribution, and we’ll raise a glass to Elizabeth and Shaquille as they step into their new roles. Expect warmth, good company, big-hearted kōrero and a few surprises too.
If you're planning to attend in person and haven’t yet booked travel, now’s a good time to do so.

BIMinNZ Wellington: Project Spotlight - Digital Workflows on Heke Rua, Pōneke — Mark Your Calendars!BIM in NZ is thrilled to announce our next Wellington event.
Join us on Thursday, 28 August at GHD for a Project Spotlight on the digital delivery of Heke Rua Archives — one of Aotearoa’s most ambitious façades, and a truly industry-leading example of BIM in action.
Hear from Revizto, Thermosash, Warren and Mahoney, and WT as they share how digital technology helped overcome the project’s extraordinary complexity — enabling seamless collaboration and unified digital workflows that crossed traditional disciplinary boundaries.
Revizto will kick things off with a short sponsor presentation, highlighting how their platform supported project delivery from design through to construction.
Roja from Thermosash will share how their team continues to evolve digital workflows to meet the demands of an ever-changing, collaborative landscape — and the unique challenges of delivering a façade of this scale.
Finally, Alex and Anton — fresh off a headline talk at DigiComm25 — will dive into the BIM coordination process and digital twin, exploring how this project sets a new benchmark for digital delivery in Aotearoa.

This event brings together educators, coaches, counsellors, and mentors for a day of meaningful conversations, keynote presentations, and practical breakout sessions focused on improving boys’ engagement, behaviour, and social connectedness.
Why attend?
Learn practical strategies to connect with boys and young men
Gain insights on classroom engagement, behaviour management, and building respect
Discover how to harness student culture and involve parents/whānau
Hear from world-class experts in education, leadership, and boys’ development
Speakers include:
Dr Ray Swann — Executive Director, Positive Masculinity Foundation
Dr Mark Dowley — Author, The Classroom Management Handbook
Kristen Molloy — Associate Head, The Crowther Centre
Ingrid Howren — Leadership Coach & +M Curriculum Specialist
Dr Aaron Columbus — Deputy Principal Teaching & Learning, Wellington College
Special Keynote: Professor Matt Englar-Carlson — Co-Director, Center for Men and Boys, California State University, leading expert on positive masculinity and mental health
Details:
Ticket includes morning tea & lunch
Accommodation advice available for out-of-town attendees (contact Dr Aaron Columbus at Wellington College)
This is a rare opportunity to learn from international leaders and collaborate with peers passionate about helping boys thrive.

Women in finance lunch, with speaker Christina Leung, CFA, Welcome to the Women in Finance Lunch event! Join us for an inspiring talk by Christina Leung, CFA at Forsyth Barr. This in-person event will bring together women in the finance industry to network, learn, and empower each other. Don't miss this opportunity to hear from a successful professional and connect with like-minded individuals. Reserve your spot now!
We're pleased to invite our members and CFA candidates to another Women in Finance lunch, this time with guest speaker; CFA charterholder, Christina Leung, CFA, Deputy Chief Executive & Principal Economist, NZIER
About our presenter
Christina Leung, CFA is Vice Chair of the CFA Society New Zealand and Deputy Chief Executive (Auckland) and Principal Economist at the NZ Institute of Economic Research (NZIER), where she looks after economic forecasts and analysis of the Quarterly Survey of Business Opinion. Christina also works with many clients looking at topical issues, including the wider economic impact of particular industries and investments. She previously worked at the Reserve Bank of New Zealand and ASB. Christina holds a Bachelor of Commerce with first class honours in Economics.
Christina will talk about her career journey and share her experiences of being a woman in the world of economics and finance.
Bring a friend
We invite members and candidates to bring along a colleague, please register for catering purposes.
Men are very welcome too!
As with previous events, we understand you're busy. It's okay to arrive late, or leave early, we'd just like to see you.

description:
Strengths & Superpowers, Strengths & Superpowers
Personal branding isn’t showing off - it’s taking ownership over how you’re perceived. Join a Masterclass in making yours standout among the rest.
Welcome to the second conversation in our Women in Business series: four events that bring you important conversations led by Women in Business and heard by everyone. In partnership with Forsyth Barr, this bar-setting series is bringing hard-hitting topics into the conversational spotlight.
This conversation is led by two experts who are empowering other women, and will focus on an often-overlooked asset: personal branding. Whether your sights are set on a project or a promotion, this powerful tool can put you on the radar for the opportunities you want.
Why be part of this conversation?
When you control your narrative, you can ensure that it's accurate, compelling, and unique. Join our interactive session to uncover and learn how to convey the unique value you bring to the table. It isn't about crafting a fake persona, it's about making sure your superpowers get noticed.
You’ll get expert insights into:
Strengths: Understand and use your strengths for impact.
Superpower: Take control of what you want to be known for.
Story: Quick ways to naturally share your value.
Who’s the speaker?
Natalie Ferguson & Kristen Luman are the founders of Powrsuit - a career accelerator for every woman that takes professional development out of to-do lists and into weekly routines. With over 700 members across NZ, Australia, North America and Singapore, Powrsuit's research-backed approach delivers a tangible return on investment. After six months, 82% of members increase self-leadership skills, and 28% take a tangible step forward in their careers.
This interactive workshop is a must-attend for anyone who wants to maximise their visibility and value, regardless of job title.
**All attendees will go into the draw to win a annual Powrsuit membership**
What’s in-store:
5:15-5:30pm – Arrival/networking
5:30-6:15pm – Powrsuit mini-masterclass
6:15-6:30pm – Q&A
6:30-7:30pm – Networking with drinks & canapes
This event is part of the Women in Business chapter from our “Join the Conversation” series - 4 events that spotlight important topics through conversation, led by the amazing women driving change within them.

Attend the event and go in the draw to win a “New BMW for a Weekend” and a “New MINI for a Weekend” from Continental Cars BMW and Wellington MINI Garage.

description:
ECD Emotional Leadership Development Course 20th November - Central Wellington, ECD Emotional Leadership Development 1 Day Certification Course
Become a Certified Emotional Culture Deck Leadership Practitioner
This course is designed to enhance leadership development by equipping leaders with the tools to understand and manage emotional drivers and dynamics within themselves, their people and their teams. The course focuses on developing emotionally aware leaders who can effectively foster a positive workplace culture. Participants will engage in practical activities that promote self-awareness, team cohesion, and emotional intelligence, all grounded in The Emotional Culture Deck framework.
"Emotional culture is shaped by how all employees—from the highest echelons to the front lines—comport themselves day in and day out. But it’s up to senior leaders to establish which emotions will help the organization thrive, model those emotions, and reward others for doing the same. Companies in which they do this have a lot to gain." – Sigal Barsade & Olivia O'Neil, Manage Your Emotional Culture

Why this course is a Game-Changer

In today’s fast-paced and complex business environment, the ability to lead with emotion is more critical than ever. Our ECD Emotional Leadership Development Course is designed to transform the way leaders understand and harness the power of emotions to foster a more dynamic and responsive workplace.
What to expect
This hands-on one-day course is designed for immediate application, ensuring that you can translate insights into action as soon as you return to your team or clients. 
What to expect from this 1 day course experience:
Understanding the power of emotions in leading others effectively
Development of effective emotion-led leadership strategies. 
Learning how to use and embed our ready-made Emotional Culture Deck Leadership Tools
Active learning through interactive activities and group discussions.
Exploration of personal leadership and team leadership.
What's included in this course?
Enrol in the ECD Emotional Leadership Development Course and unlock a wealth of resources including:
ECD Emotional Leadership Development Toolkit - Valued at 175 NZD: Get this invaluable toolkit filled with a robust selection of physical and downloadable resources designed for immediate impact. Its comprehensive nature will extend your learning and application of the course content well beyond the Course.
1x Emotional Culture Deck  - Valued at 155 NZD: Receive your personal ECD, an essential tool for applying courseprinciples in real-world settings, adding even more value to your toolkit.
Exclusive 60-Minute Group Coaching Call: Enhance your course experience with a group coaching call, scheduled six to eight weeks post-course. Hosted via Zoom, this session provides an opportunity to solidify your learning, address any questions, and ensure you're applying your new skills effectively. Whether you attend live or watch the replay later, this call is a key step in your continued development.
Continued Learning Discount: Enjoy a 50% discount on future purchases of The Emotional Culture Deck to support your ongoing practice.
ECD Emotional Leadership Certificate of Practice: A formal acknowledgement of your dedication to enhancing your Emotional Culture Deck skills. This certificate serves as a testament to your commitment to emotional leadership and amplifying human conversations about what really matters in the workplace
90-Day All Access Pass to our Online Elephant Rider Community: By enrolling, you gain access to an ECD Emotional Leadership package with resources, expertise, and continued support, all designed to flip the traditional approach to leadership development
Gain access to an ECD Emotional Leadership package with resources, expertise, and continued support, all designed to flip the traditional approach to leadership development.



Is this course right for you?
This course is great for executives, leaders and managers within organisations as well as those who consult or coach on leadership, culture and emotional intelligence. 
The course is ideal for:
HR Professionals: Who aim to enhance leadership qualities and traits and train their leaders to develop emotional intelligence within the workplace.
Leadership Coaches: Dedicated to developing emotionally smart leadership practices in diverse environments.
Organisation Development Managers: Focused on building adaptable, resilient organisational cultures through effective leadership.
Coaches and Consultants: Specialising in personal and professional and personal leadership development.
Project Leaders: Committed to managing project teams with empathy and emotional insight.
Team Leads and Supervisors: Looking to improve team cohesion and performance through emotional awareness.
Aspiring and experienced leaders: You could be a developing leader OR if you are an experienced leader who wants to develop in the emotional leadership space then this course is for you.
Whether you are leading initiatives within your organisation or providing expert advice to others, the Emotional Leadership Development Course provides the tools and insights necessary to develop more effective, emotionally aware leaders and teams.
What previous participants had to say about this workshop.
10/10 - "Giving everyone regardless of their emotional literacy a way to express themselves and to form authentic connections is genius! Learning how to use this to help teams and organisations change their emotional culture in an intentional way is super exciting! Lotty was an amazing facilitator. Her energy and passion were 100% contagious. Her approach gentle and inclusive. I’d do it again in a heartbeat!" - Cordula Plassmann
9/10 - "This course opened my eyes to how emotions can be surfaced and navigated in leadership. A key takeaway was that we all have emotions, it's how we surface and leverage them." - Julia Anderson
10/10 - "A wonderful investment! Highly recommend this course to anyone looking to strengthen their collaboration and people leadership skills. Great fun, very practical and helpful tools to use in a wide variety of situations." - Rosaleen Smith
10/10 - "This course was truly inspiring and deeply motivating. Its mission to rehumanise workplaces and life really resonates with me and I’m excited to put these learnings into action.  Lotty was amazing - She has a very special way of explaining things. I was massively inspired and very empowered." - Phoebe Edge
10/10 - "Lotty was (and is) amazing, the size of the group was perfect for me, the amount of content and the explanations of how and when to use them was explicit, doing an in-person workshop was so much more useful to me personally. I've gained a load more confidence and I am excited to share what I learned." - Kelley Oliver
10/10 - "Extremely meaningful and engaging - a wonderful opportunity to first look internally at how I lead myself in order to focus on and improve how I achieve and support effective emotional leadership of my team." - Karinna McDonald
10/10 - "Absolutely loved it. I now feel informed and equipped to facilitate emotional culture conversations and workshops. Such important and powerful stuff - I believe every leader should know about and understand the difference between cognitive and emotional culture, in order to enable a truly thriving workforce. Lotty is an incredible facilitator - bringing energy, insight, kindness, and passion" - Teressa Betty
What is the Emotional Culture Deck?

The Emotional Culture Deck (ECD) is the number one game in the world for better workplace culture designed and created by Jeremy Dean of riders&elephants.
The ECD is currently used by over 400,000 people in over 55+ countries, it is a uniquely powerful way to create human conversations about what really matters in the workplace. 
The game facilitates face-to-face human conversations about what matters. It nudges vulnerability. Builds empathy. Creates connections and fosters trust within teams.
It's the ultimate card game toolkit for more successful and human workplaces.
Click here to learn more about The ECD and watch the origin story video below of the founder of riders&elephants sharing the story behind the game.
Join Lotty and learn how to use the Emotional Culture Deck to enhance your leadership
Learn from one of the worlds most experienced Emotional Culture Deck Consultants and Facilitators - Lotty Roberts, Founder of MiND.U, Master Elephant Rider and Certified ECD consultant .
Lotty Roberts is an Emotional Culture Coach, Consultant and Facilitator. Since completing the ECD Masterclass Course in 2018, Lotty has become one of the most experienced Emotional Culture Deck consultants in the world and the first to ever become a Master Level Certified ECD Consultant. Lotty has delivered over 200 Emotional Culture Deck client workshops, as well as dozens of 1:2:1's, helping teams of all sizes, in a variety of industries create more healthy and high performing cultures. 
Lotty is also a regular on the speaking circuit delivering talks and presentations on all aspects of emotional culture including change, leadership and resilience.
Lotty's speciality and passion is all about helping leaders, teams and cultures to thrive, flourish and flow in a fast paced world, through the power of mindfulness and embracing emotions.
Lotty is the founder of her business, ‘MiND.U’, where she is devoted to helping companies and individuals build the emotional capability, resilience and wisdom to navigate the ever changing, complex and dynamic world we find ourselves in.
Will refreshments be provided during the workshop?
Coffee, tea, water and some light snacks will be available during the morning tea break but you will need to bring or buy your own lunch.
What's the refund and cancellation policy?
Unfortunately, ECD Certified Consultants don’t offer refunds for this workshop experience. 
However, you may send someone else in your place to this workshop if you cannot attend for any reason.
You must notify your Workshop host that you will not attend the workshop and the name of the person that will attend in your spot.
If you cannot attend the workshop, and no one attends in your place, the workshop organiser will post your ECD Emotional Leadership Development Workshop Kit to you (Value 330 NZD) – so you don’t miss out completely.
If the Workshop Host cancels this workshop, you will be transferred to the next available workshop. You can contact the Workshop host for a refund if you cannot attend the revised workshop date.

description:
Build your Professional Board of Directors, You’ve got colleagues to vent to, friends to debrief with, and maybe a podcast or two for inspiration… but when was the last time you had an intentional conversation about your career? It’s time to change that. 
While coaching and courses get all the attention, there's another powrful tool that often gets overlooked: a Professional Board of Directors. The women who navigate pivotal career moments best? They don't do it alone.
Just as companies need a board to guide them, you deserve a trusted circle to help with career decisions, fresh perspectives, and ongoing accountability.

This interactive 2-hour session is for women at every stage - from new graduates to senior leaders. Over a few drinks and snacks, you’ll:
Learn: What a professional board of directors is, how they work and why they’re so impactful.
Connect: We’ll pre-match you with 4-5 others at a similar stage and situation. This will be your board for the evening!
Experience: Your first board meeting. We'll provide instructions and a simple agenda.

Bonus: Your ticket comes with a free 3-month Powrsuit membership (worth $147). Designed for busy people, Powrsuit combines bite-sized learning, peer coaching, and micro-networking in one all-inclusive membership. With weekly live events and on-demand access through our web and mobile apps, you will make step-by-step progress in your career, on your terms.
Note: While all genders are welcome in the Powrsuit network, this event is for Women+. Want to join as an Ally or learn more about what we do? Get in touch.

Compliance made SME-asy: Employment basics with ATH Consulting, Are you confident in navigating the complexities of employment relationships in today’s ever-changing workplace? Join us for a comprehensive workshop designed for managers, employers, and business owners who want to deepen their understanding of employment fundamentals and people management best practices.
What You’ll Learn:
Foundations of Employment Relationships:
Explore the essential components that shape every employment relationship, including relevant legislation, terms and conditions, and the pivotal role of workplace policies and procedures.
Understanding Employment Types:
Distinguish between permanent, full-time, casual, and seasonal roles, and learn how each type impacts your obligations and management strategies.
Employment Legislation Essentials:
Get a practical overview of the 10 key employment laws that influence your workplace, ensuring you stay compliant and informed.
Good Faith and Agreements:
Discover the importance of acting in good faith and the differences between Individual Employment Agreements (IEA) and Collective Employment Agreements (CEA), including mandatory clauses and recommended “nice to have” terms.
Managing Change:
Learn best practices for handling variations to employment agreements and implementing effective workplace policies and procedures.
People Management Mastery:
Gain insights into the employee lifecycle, building a strong employment brand, and managing common workplace issues such as performance improvement plans (PiP), disciplinary processes, attendance, and health and wellbeing.
Leadership and Succession:
Identify the hallmarks of poor leadership and develop strategies for effective succession planning to future-proof your team.
Support Systems:
Know where to get help—learn when to trust your gut, when to rely on facts, and how to access the right support at the right time.
This workshop is your opportunity to build confidence, reduce risk, and enhance your leadership toolkit. Whether you’re new to managing people or looking to refresh your knowledge, you’ll leave with practical insights and actionable strategies for every stage of the employment relationship.
Don’t miss this chance to strengthen your employment management skills and connect with peers facing similar challenges. Register now and take the next step toward becoming a more effective, knowledgeable, and resilient leader.
When: Wednesday 10 September 9.00 am - 11.00 am
Where: Carterton Community Courthouse (next to Events Centre) Holloway Street, Carterton
Cost: Members $65 + GST, Non-Members $120 +GST
This workshop needs a minimum of 15 attendees to go ahead.

description:
Empowering Aotearoa New Zealand’s Digital Future, You’re invited to the launch of NZTech’s latest landmark report: Empowering Aotearoa New Zealand’s Digital Future – Our National Data Centre Infrastructure.
Data centres are the backbone of our digital lives, powering everything from essential government services and healthcare to banking, e-commerce, and artificial intelligence (AI).  As data centre demand rises, so does the need for a resilient and sustainable energy supply. This sector is playing a pivotal role in New Zealand’s transition to a low-carbon future and helping to future-proof the electricity grid.
Discover what’s really happening with New Zealand’s booming data centre sector and what it means for our economy, communities and our digital future. Meet the data centre operators and electricity providers driving this transformation, and hear directly from Hon Simon Watts, Minister for Energy and Climate Change, and Graeme Muller, CEO, NZTech.
 Join us and find out:
how data centres power our everyday lives and the scale of New Zealand’s data centre sector
how the sector is fuelling economic growth and generating thousands of jobs
why New Zealand’s data centres are global leaders in energy efficiency and driving investment in new wind, solar and geothermal projects
how New Zealand is uniquely positioned to become a regional hub for sustainable digital exports.
the importance of collaboration between government and industry to ensure renewable energy supply can keep pace with digital growth. 
Learn more about how the digital economy and energy sector are working together to unlock new value for all New Zealanders, ensuring our country thrives in a rapidly evolving digital world.

description:

If you’ve been thinking that you need to start working ON your business
(rather than just IN the business), or maybe you are feeling unsure of
where to focus your efforts, or perhaps you are even becoming

description:
Leadership Play Day - Wellington, Leadership Play Day: Wellington 17th October 2025
Friday 17th October 2025 | 8:30am–5:00pm
Location: Nairn Street Cottage, 68 Nairn Street, Mount Cook, Wellington 6011

What this day is all about
Leadership Play Day is a full-day, game-based learning experience that takes leadership development out of the boardroom and into play. Instead of being talked at with boring slides, you’ll step into three carefully designed games that let you actually practice leadership.
You’ll be experimenting, problem-solving, laughing (a lot), and walking away with insights that stick because you’ve lived them, not just heard them.
This isn’t theory. It’s leadership in action.
Learn more at our website.
How it works
The day is made up of three 2-hour games. You can book individual sessions ($99 each), or join us for the full day ($297) to play all three and unlock The Leadership Playbook - a bonus 60-minute facilitated debrief where we connect the dots and help you take away a clear set of personal leadership shifts.
Here’s what’s on in Wellington:
The Moonlit Market (8:30–10:30am)
Pitch, trade, and negotiate under pressure. Build agility, creativity, and bold decision-making in a playful, high-energy marketplace.
The Broken Bridge (11:00am–1:00pm)
A fantasy quest to practice difficult conversations. Explore courage, clarity, and how you show up when the stakes feel high.
The Inner Tides (1:45–3:45pm)
Use the Emotional Culture Deck in a role-playing game to strengthen emotional awareness, resilience, and confidence in leading with empathy.
The Leadership Playbook (4:00–5:00pm)
Available only with a full-day pass. A guided reflection session to connect your learning, extract insights, and leave with a practical playbook you can use back at work.
Why you should join
Practical skills, not theory - you’ll walk away with tools and insights you can use immediately.
Safe practice, real challenges - rehearse tough moments without real-world consequences.
Energy + engagement - no sitting back, you’ll be on your feet, in the mix, learning by doing.
Unique approach - game-based leadership development you won’t find anywhere else in NZ.
Whether you’re a leader, facilitator, HR/People professional, or just someone curious about growing your leadership edge - this day is designed for you.
Tickets
Individual game session: $99
Full day pass (all 3 games + Leadership Playbook debrief): $297
👉 Ready to roll the dice on your leadership?

Spots are limited - grab your ticket today.

Monthly Topic: Powerful Email Marketing
Hosted by: Bryony Richardson
This month, we’re diving into Powerful Email Marketing, because your inbox might be the most underestimated goldmine in your business. Whether you’re building community, driving sales, or nurturing long-term clients, email marketing allows you to connect on a deeper level (without having to battle the unpredictable social media algorithm).
In September, we’ll be sharing ideas, swapping tips, and uncovering what makes a newsletter not just opened but loved. From juicy subject lines to irresistible calls-to-action, get ready to rethink the power of your email list.

description:
Dare to Lead™ | Wellington | 22-24 September 2025, The ultimate starting point for brave leaders, courageous cultures and organisational change.

"Highly recommend."
"Inspiring."
"An amazing experience."
"One 'aha moment' after the other."

Founded on the research of Dr. Brené Brown, Dare to Lead™ is an empirically based courage-building programme, delivered by Boma New Zealand CEO and Certified Dare to Lead™ Facilitator Kaila Colbin.
Brené has spent two decades studying shame and more than seven years specifically looking at leadership. During her research, she interviewed leaders from all over the world — from Fortune 100 companies, non-profits, public sector entities, and more — and asked one question: what is the future of leadership?
Remarkably, their answers pointed to one thing: we need braver leaders.

We need more courage.

The most significant finding from Brené’s latest research, and the foundation of Dare to Lead™, is that courage is a collection of four skill sets that are teachable, measurable, and observable.

After completing the three-day Dare to Lead™ programme you'll understand how to:
Effectively navigate vulnerability and unlock change
Turn values from fluffy language into tangible, practical behaviours
Build a common culture of trust in your team
Cultivate the skills to rise from setbacks and be more resilient

This curriculum is essential for teams who want to:
Be better equipped to deal with difficult conversations
Reduce unhealthy and unproductive behaviour
Be more creative and innovative
Build resilience and improve alignment
Foster a culture of accountability and trust

This experience is for you if:
You're in a position of leadership within your organisation
You see the potential in people and processes, and are willing to take responsibility for achieving that potential
You’re passionate about accelerating performance in yourself and others
You have to navigate organisational change as part of your role

Need help with the cost?
If you are an Educator or at a Not-for-Profit, you can automatically access a special price of $1,995 + GST when you register.
We also have partial scholarships available to attend the programme. Apply here and we’ll be in touch.
Boma is a Regional Business Network Provider. Your organisation may be eligible for funding support to attend this programme. Find out more at regionalbusinesspartners.co.nz

Our Health and Safety Plan
Boma is committed to delivering safe events. We follow best practices suggested by the New Zealand health authorities and work closely with our suppliers to prioritise health and wellbeing.
Our comprehensive health and safety plans ensure you can book with certainty and attend with confidence.

Our refund policy
For details on event refunds and transfers, please see our refund policy.

Contact us
Please email hello@boma.global with any questions.

description:
Intro to Musical Improv | A PopRox Improv Course, Musical improv can be absolute magic. Whether it's a whole musical show, or single song that bursts out of an emotional scene, music adds so much to our improv.
This course for improvisers will give an introduction to musical improv. We'll cover basic song structures, how to get into a song from a scene, how to support a song through chorus work, and why and when we use music to add to our improv.
Participants should be confident in scene-work and have at least 2 years improv experience. This course will not teach you how to approach scenes and characters, so you should have a solid foundation which you can add to with this new toolbox of musical skills.
The course includes 6 workshops which will run 6:30pm to 8:30pm on Wednesdays from August 6th to September 10th. As it is an intro course, we do not anticipate a showcase for this course.
ABOUT THE TEACHERS
LIA KELLY is a theatre-maker and teacher based in Pōneke. She is an established director, actor, improviser and musician and has been a part of productions across the city over the last 10 years. She directed One Night Band which won 'Most Original Production' at the Wellington Theatre Awards 2023, and performs regularly as both a player and musician for POPROX.
ISAAC THOMAS has been an improviser and improv musician for a decade in Pōneke and Whakatū/Nelson. He's played with Body in Space, Playshop, Poprox and been musical director for musical improv powerhouse The Pāua Ballads. He has worked with almost every major improv company around the city accompanying them through improvised piano, guitar and vocals.
THE STANDY-BY LIST
PopRox firmly believes that improv is for everyone, especially when it comes to sharing skills and knowledge. So we're offering "the stand-by list" for all our workshops in 2025. We'll giveaway any spots remaining a few days before the first workshop of the course, on a first-come-first-serve basis. No need to provide a reason, no questions asked. If the entry fee is a barrier for you to come along, then simply email poproximprov@gmail.com and we'll pop you on the SBL. Everyone on the list will be notified whether there was a place available for them 3 days before the first workshop.

description:
Advanced Claw Setting in Two Days, This two-day class will run on two Sundays, 24 and 31 August, 10am - 1pm. It is designed for advanced students and focuses on teaching a range of claw setting techniques, along with straightforward construction methods to securely hold gemstones of various shapes and sizes. The emphasis is on mastering the techniques rather than creating polished, finished jewellery pieces.
Students are encouraged to bring along their own particular tools, metal and stones if they would like to. They can also bring their own half made ring shanks or other projects to set into.
They will start by creating claw settings for flat-bottomed stones on plate to gain an understanding of how claws work.
Students will then move on to faceted stones and be shown how to construct their own settings in a number of styles, and how to secure their stones in settings. Finally, they will be taught the dos and don’ts of finishing settings to a salable level.
The workshop will also look at how to use pre-made claw settings to best advantage.
Workshop fee $245, Early bird $221 till 27 July.

description:
Bailamos Bachata! Latin Dance Party (with free lesson), Please note: the event is free but it can only continue if we support the Southern Cross by buying food or drinks

Wellington’s favourite monthly Bachata Latin dance party

Join us for an awesome mix of bachata, focusing on the best sensual tracks and remixes, along with salsa and a smattering of kizomba and zouk. We welcome everyone, from the absolute beginner to the most experienced dancer. We’re all about the joy of social dancing together.
And what makes a free party with great people even better? A free beginners’ bachata lesson with some of Wellington‘s best Latin dance teachers. If you’ve never danced bachata, Latin dance or even any other dance style before then this is the perfect lesson for you. We will have you dancing like a pro in no time!
Bailamos Bachata is hosted free of charge by the Southern Cross. They love the atmosphere we bring but we also need to support them in return. We’re asking everyone attending to purchase soft drinks, food or alcohol from the bar. It’s vital we show our gratitude.
1800-1830 social
1830-1900 free lesson
1900-2100 social
Q&A
Q. What is bachata?
A. Bachata is a popular and fun Latin couples dance. It started in the Dominican Republic, then travelled to Europe and the rest of the world. It now includes a wide range of music styles and dance influences and is still changing and evolving.
Q. I haven’t danced before, is that a problem?
A. Not at all! That’s exactly what the lesson is for – everyone has to start somewhere and we’re a very welcoming crowd for beginners.
Q. Is bachata a difficult dance to learn?
A. Its origins as a party/community dance mean the basics can be learnt quite quickly, so you’ll be enjoying yourself in no time.
Q. Who are the capital bachata collective?
A. We are the combined Wellington dance schools and people teaching bachata and we really want to share this dance with everyone. We love bachata, we love our community and we want to share it with you
￼

Whether you’re a first-time weaver or returning to refresh your skills, all are welcome. We’ll cover basic weaving techniques and tikanga (customs) and provide a supportive, creative space to connect with Māori arts and crafts alongside others.
Session Times
• Open session: 1:00pm – 5:00pm (pack down starts at 4:30pm)
What to Bring
• New weavers: 5–10 rau (blades) of harakeke, sharp scissors.
• An old towel
• Bring a bag, as you must take away leftover harakeke
• Returning weavers: 30–40 rau of harakeke and your weaving tools
• Some tools are available to borrow
• Shared kai (snacks) welcome but not required
• Bring a bag, as you must take away leftover harakeke
Koha appreciated, not required
If you would like to support the kaupapa, please email us at temotukairangi.huihui@gmail.com for koha details.
Come and enjoy weaving, learning, and connection in a beautiful, relaxed setting.
Contact
via facebook
https://www.facebook.com/TeMotuKai

Email temotukairangi.huihui@gmail.com
If you would like to koha to TMK, please email (Email temotukairangi.huihui@gmail.com) for the account details.

description:
Biochar Big Day Out 2025, Char curious? Keen gardener? Orchardist? Lifestyler? Climate Champion? BBQ enthusiast? 
Come one, come all to this one-off opportunity to spend a day making biochar in a magical orchard, forest and garden. Thank you Kapiti Coast District Council (KCDC) and Paekākāriki Orchards and Gardens (POG) for sponsoring this event so we can offer subsidised tickets as part of Sustainable Spring!
You will:

Morning sessions (9.30-12)...
Sipping coffee and learning the basics of Biochar. 
Getting hands-on exploring the property and learning to source good burn material (stuff you can find in your own backyard or lifestyle block).
Building a char toilet - great skills for civil defence emergencies, or just camping!
Ignite the Char-B-Que and BIG 600l kiln, learn how to feed the flames and trap the carbon.
Cooking using char!
At lunchtime (12-1)...
Enjoy a BBQ lunch cooked on the Char-B-Que. 
Learn all about the magic of biochar and how to use it to fight climate change, feed your garden. 
After lunch sessions (1-3)...
Quenching (pour cold water on) a kiln and processing char by drying and crushing it.
Making a home fireplace mini kiln using a biscuit tin (please bring a tin if you have one or koha for some extra we will source and bring from op shops).
Making a char water filter.
At the end of the day (3 pm)
Grab some biochar to take home (BYO container e.g. ice-cream tub or a small bucket
The big kiln will be quenched later in the day (around 4pm). For those keen to level up their learning on the kind of kilns used for large lifestyle blocks and small farms you are welcome to stay on and participate in a small advanced group dicussion and actvities between 3 and 4.30pm. 
Important things to note: 
Sustainability: 
We encourage carpooling to the event. Please bring your own reusable cup for hot drinks
Health and Safety:
 Please note there will be tree nuts and hazards onsite such as hot kilns and flames. So please take the necessary precautions by wearing non-flammable (cotton, wool, natural) materials and bring any personal medication that you need. We will have a health and safety volunteer onsite.

Family Friendly:
 It is a family-friendly event (kids under 18 are free) but they must be supervised by their parent or guardian at all times due to the hazards on site. 
Workshop Leaders 
John Wraight - CharPae 
Our CharPae Operations manager and ‘inhouse’ Biochar subject matter expert John Wraight has been making and using Biochar for many years and has delivered a number of successful workshops using these kilns. He is a BioChar Network member. He leads local CharPae burns, Char-B-Ques and kiln hire.
Holly Norton - CharPae 
Our CharPae Project manager has been making and using Biochar for the past 2 years. She co-leads these workshops and has additionally been exploring char use in sustainable construction and civil defence. She is currently on a mission to use Biochar to transform a tennis court into a thriving kai production space. She is this event's coordinator should you have any questions.

description:
The Art of Mending, When it comes to the clothes we love, every rip, stain, and imperfection is an invitation to exercise agency, expression, and an opportunity to show the garment how much we appreciate it.
This class is cared for by the whimsical Aisha, a multidisciplinary artist with a passion for empowering the mending process. Each month on Wednesday evenings Aisha will introduce us to a different technique for reviving our beloved textile pieces. If you're like us and have a box of clothing in need of repairs that never seems to empty... this is the club for you. With three events a month we'll inspire each other to creatively care for those pieces we love! This club is also perfect for anyone who loves learning new skills. Techniques we'll cover are lino printing, patching, darning, felting, embroidery, beading, sashiko, fabric painting and more! All materials and tools are supplied at each class - but you are welcome to bring your own. We highly encourage bringing those clothes or other textile items that need some love and repair.
There is no need to attend every class. We can catch you up on the skill at which ever class you choose to join us at. There are single class tickets or monthly sign ups available. Both of these have variable pricing options, unwaged/student, waged, and generous. Please choose whichever option feels right for you and your circumstances!
In August we are Lino Printing!
Class 02: 20th August
At this class Aisha will take us through the process of designing and cutting our own lino to print with! You're welcome to keep going with the pre cut designs as well. Lino and carving tools will be supplied.
Class 03: 27th August
This class will be open to what you want to work on! Bring in larger project items, print with the lino cuts you made in the previous week, or cut some fresh ones!
In September we are patching!
Class 01: 10th September
Aisha will take us through the process of sewing on patches. Patches that we printed in the August classes will be available for this. You're welcome to bring your own patches as well. Please bring something that needs a patch up or a little bit of decoration.
Class 02: 17th September
At this class we will learn how to appliqué, the process of using scrap fabric to make decorative patches. This is a great way to elevate a rip or stain with some visible mending.
Class 03: 24th September
At this last class of the month we'll be open for all the patching needs. Hang out and finish projects we've started or mend some extra items.
Be sure to check our website or here for updates about techniques coming up in the following months.

description:
2-Day Kali Seminar with Stephen Brown from Inosanto Academy in CA, Want to learn the exact martial art skills as used in the Bourne films? Wellington this is your chance...
Tactical Survival Academy is hosting Senior Instructor Stephen Brown from the renowned Inosanto Academy of Martial Arts in Marina Del Rey, Los Angeles!
With over 40 years of martial arts experience and 36 years training under Guro Dan Inosanto, Stephen is one of only two instructors currently teaching Kali classes at the academy alongside Guro Dan Inosanto himself.
Stephen specializes in the Filipino Martial Art of Kali, as passed down through Guro Inosanto’s lineage. His training background also includes extensive experience in Muay Thai, Silat, Western Boxing, Jeet Kune Do, Savate and Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu.
Over the decades, Stephen has worked with:
* Multiple branches of Law Enforcement, Military units and Special Forces.
* Actors, stunt performers, and executives in the film and television industry.
* As a fight choreographer for screen productions.
Known for his precision, adaptability, and deep respect for the cultural roots of the arts he teaches, Stephen brings a wealth of knowledge and embodied experience to every seminar.
Currently based in Marina Del Rey, CA, Stephen is excited to share the Kali method of Guro Inosanto with the New Zealand martial arts community.
• Location: Mt Cook School Hall, 160 Tory Street, Te Aro
• Dates: Sat Sept 6 + Sun Sept 7
• Time: 1:30pm – 4:30pm (both days)
• Cost: One Day Only (Sat or Sun) $140 / Both Days $260
• Registration Closing Date: Wed Sept 3rd
Bookings Email: contact@tacticalsurvival.co.nz

description:
Bakery & Brewery, Step into the world of baking and brewing with this unforgettable experience. Join owner Tim Tracey at the Dough Bakery HQ for an interactive hands-on class where you'll master the art of sourdough. Learn the techniques behind creating the perfect loaf, from mixing to baking, in this immersive workshop.

After you’ve perfected your sourdough skills, it’s time to head over to Upper Hutt’s Brewtown via the Tradesman Entrance, where you’ll get an exclusive tour of Boneface Brewery. Discover the secrets behind their craft beers, and enjoy an inside look at the brewing process, from hops to pint.

The adventure culminates with a delicious BBQ smoked-meat dinner, where you can unwind, savouring expertly smoked meats in a relaxed, welcoming atmosphere. Whether you’re a culinary enthusiast, a craft beer lover, or simply in search of a great night out, this event offers a perfect blend of hands-on cooking, beer appreciation, and mouthwatering food.

This is your chance to learn from the best and indulge in an evening of flavour and fun!

You'll finish by choosing your preferred glaze colours, and we'll take care of the firing process. Your finished butter dish will be ready to collect approximately four weeks later.
This small group workshop is perfect for absolute beginners—no experience needed. Come solo and meet like-minded creatives, or bring a friend for a fun and mindful morning.

description:
Integrating Creative Writing Into Painting - 4 Week Course, Creative writing and painting are both powerful forms of artistic expression. By integrating creative writing into your painting practice, you can enhance your imagination, storytelling abilities, emotional expression, attention to detail, and personal style on the canvas. Please bring along a journal or laptop.

COURSE CONTENT
Each session presents a key idea backed by research or concrete examples, followed by practical writing exercises with optional sharing. We learn by doing and from each other.

1. Generating work from the interior: tapping into memories, conflict, emotion, and observation to generate art.
2. Figuring out what matters to you, then learning how to grow your fragmented ideas into something whole. For example, how do you turn a feeling, or a fleeting moment in time into a story? Into a painting? Into a work of art? What are the building blocks you need?
3. Inspiration from other creative sources: people, music, poetry, reading, random incidents. Ways to generate fresh ideas. How to clarify and focus in writing and art.
4. Structure and boundaries. Dreaming big but being real. How do you find and stick to a creative process? Understanding how you learn and what kind of feedback you need. Designing your next project.

Thursday mornings, 9:30 - 11:45 am.
4 - 25 September.

description:
Jewellery Making Intensive - Beginners' Workshop, Join us for a fun day learning the skills to make your own jewellery, using sterling silver and copper or brass. All materials included in course fee.

Description
Learn the essential skills and techniques needed to make your own creations. The morning will begin with simple design examples and techniques using specialist jewellers’ tools, working with copper or brass. In the afternoon you will form and craft your own ring from sterling silver.

All materials included in course fee. Please bring pen and paper and wear clothing and footwear suitable for a workshop environment. Limited to nine participants.
Please note you cannot be late for this one-day course, you must be there from the start of the course when health and safety matters are covered.

By the end of the course, you'll be able to:
- Create a silver band
- Demonstrate techniques for soldering sterling silver
- Perform metal forming, piercing and texturing skills
- Use essential jewellery-making tools accurately

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

description:
Glass Bead-Making Taster, Join us for this fabulous introduction to working with colourful molten glass!

This class is a great way for absolute beginners to get a taste of working with glass to produce beautiful beads that can be used in a myriad of ways, including making a unique gift for your loved one (or yourself!).

As one of the earliest forms of human adornment, beads have long functioned as a way to express individuality, and what better way to do that than to learn to make your own unique beads?

Students are shown correct lampworking techniques to produce several decorative beads in just 3 hours! How many beads you make is up to you, some students make up to 10 while others make fewer using trickier techniques.

Kids over 12 (or so) are welcome to take the class but anyone under 16 must be accompanied by an enrolled parent or caregiver.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Textured Rings - Welcome Spring!, Make your own personalised ring - a gift for yourself or someone special! :-)

Learn the basic technique first in copper or brass, and then craft your final piece in silver!

Over this taster class, you’ll be guided through the process of heating and texturing metal, cutting and shaping with traditional jewellery tools. Use feathers, leaves, or fabrics to create a unique texture for a beautiful ring!

Learn to measure your finger, cut metal to length and texture it without rolling mill, hammers and punches. Then use a jewellers torch, sandpaper and polishing, and your beautiful new ring will be ready to wear.

This 3-hour class is ideal for beginners, groups of friends and visitors to the city.

Included in the class fee are copper and brass for practising on, a sterling silver ring strip and all consumables such as sandpaper, solder and chemicals. Extra metals are available for purchase in the studio.

Kids aged 12 (or so) are welcome to attend the class, but any person under the age of 16 must be accompanied by an enrolled parent or caregiver.

description:
Glass Jewellery-making - 4-week Block, Join us for this fabulous block of classes in glass jewellery-making! The course starts on Thursday 11 September and runs for 4 weeks until Thursday 2 October, 5.30pm - 8.30pm.

This course is a great way for beginners and those with some experience to get into working with glass to produce beautiful beads that can be used in a myriad of ways.

Students will learn correct tool use and gain a solid understanding of the lampwork process. They will also learn some ways of incorporating their beads into wearable jewellery with silver and/or stainless-steel findings

Course cost includes set materials, such as glass and stainless-steel findings. Silver, findings and extra glass are available to purchase in the studio.

People under 16 must be accompanied by an enrolled parent or caregiver.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Leadlight Glass - 4 Weeks Block, Learn to create gorgeous leadlight designs with our experienced jewellers! This great course runs from Friday 12 September for 4 weeks until Friday 3 October, 5.30pm - 8pm.

Your 4-week block will give you time to learn the basics and then create one or more leadlight projects.

This class is ideal for creating sun-catchers or small decorative projects for beginners, or working on slightly more complex pieces for those with some experience.

Beginners will start by planning their design, then learning to cut the glass, and prepare it before foiling and soldering each piece, creating a simple elegant clear glass starter project.

Beautiful coloured glass, copper foil and leadlight solder are then available to purchase as required for your other projects.

This is a warm and friendly class with excellent support and learning for complete beginners and more advanced students. All tools are supplied, though you are welcome to bring your own tools and glass if you have them.

Your materials for your beginner project are supplied as part of your course fee, extra materials will be available for purchase if you wish to make larger pieces or more than one project.

description:
The Art of Mending - Micro Mill, When it comes to the clothes we love, every rip, stain, and imperfection is an invitation to exercise agency, expression, and an opportunity to show the garment how much we appreciate it.

This class is cared for by the whimsical Aisha, a multidisciplinary artist with a passion for empowering the mending process. Each month on Wednesday evenings Aisha will introduce us to a different technique for reviving our beloved textile pieces. If you're like us and have a box of clothing in need of repairs that never seems to empty... this is the club for you. With three events a month we'll inspire each other to creatively care for those pieces we love! This club is also perfect for anyone who loves learning new skills. Techniques we'll cover are lino printing, patching, darning, felting, embroidery, beading, sashiko, fabric painting and more! All materials and tools are supplied at each class - but you are welcome to bring your own. We highly encourage bringing those clothes or other textile items that need some love and repair.

There is no need to attend every class. We can catch you up on the skill at which ever class you choose to join us at. There are single class tickets or monthly sign ups available. Both of these have variable pricing options, unwaged/student, waged, and generous. Please choose whichever option feels right for you and your circumstances!

In August we are Lino Printing!
Class 02: 20th August
At this class Aisha will take us through the process of designing and cutting our own lino to print with! You're welcome to keep going with the pre cut designs as well. Lino and carving tools will be supplied.

Class 03: 27th August
This class will be open to what you want to work on! Bring in larger project items, print with the lino cuts you made in the previous week, or cut some fresh ones!

In September we are patching!
Class 01: 10th September
Aisha will take us through the process of sewing on patches. Patches that we printed in the August classes will be available for this. You're welcome to bring your own patches as well. Please bring something that needs a patch up or a little bit of decoration.

Class 02: 17th September
At this class we will learn how to appliqué, the process of using scrap fabric to make decorative patches. This is a great way to elevate a rip or stain with some visible mending.

Class 03: 24th September
At this last class of the month we'll be open for all the patching needs. Hang out and finish projects we've started or mend some extra items.

Be sure to check our website or here for updates about techniques coming up in the following months.

description:
Lost Wax in Three Sessions - Hard Wax, Over three sessions create stunning jewellery using the age-old lost wax technique. This is an excellent opportunity to treat yourself to some creative fun!

In weeks one and two you'll learn how to work with jeweller's hard wax to create beautiful textures in metal that can be used to create amazing rings or objects. Your waxes will be sent away for casting in the metal of your choice.

Then there will be a week's break before the third session, to allow time for everyone's waxes to be cast. The third session covers how to trim, clean and finish your casts, turning them into original jewellery ready to wear!

More advanced students can use these sessions to complete projects in a class setting.

Included in the class fee are all your different types of waxes, sandpaper and courier costs.

Not included are the casting and metal costs which vary from student to student depending on what sized ring they want to make and the type of metal you choose. Small castings can cost around $6.65 - $12 and might cost between $7 to $30 in metals depending on if you use red bronze, white bronze or silver.

This class is great for teens and kids over 12 or so. Anyone under 16 must be accompanied by an enrolled parent or caregiver.

If you've always wanted to try your hand at making something out of leather, but didn't know how, this is your chance. You may come with your own idea or use the templates that The Leathery provides. Common projects in the beginners class include belts, pouches, wristbands, journal covers, wallet/card holders, and many other items that can made in a day workshop. You need have no experience as you will learn skills with the tutors help. Tim has over 50 years experience.
Here is the schedule:

description:
Jewellery-making in 4 weeks on Sundays, Mixed levels - Wellington, This Sunday afternoon block is a short course on jewellery-making. It starts on Sun 24 August and runs for 4 weeks until Sun 14 September, 2pm - 5pm.
Beginners will practice the basic techniques in copper or brass and then move on to working in silver. An excellent first project for beginners in this class is to create a simple textured ring band - but once you have the basics down, it is fun to create earrings, pendants or other simple items. Learning to cut, heat, form and texture metal - to solder using a jeweller's torch and silver solder, and finally to polish your work up to a beautiful finish: these classes are super satisfying.
These blocks are also a nice way for existing students or more advanced makers to work on more challenging projects and join friendly classes in our well-equipped warm studio!
Basic materials are supplied and there are extra materials available to purchase as you need in class.
This block is great for teens and kids over 12 or so. NOTE: Anyone under 16 must be accompanied by an enrolled parent or caregiver.
Our booking system asks for full payment to be made via credit card, Afterpay or PayPal on booking. If you do not have access to these payment methods or need to pay your course fee over time please email us to arrange this
Course fee $280, Early bird pricing $252 till 27 July.

description:
Brazilian Zouk Dance Classes - Beginners Block B, Connect with other like minded people that have a love of dance.
Brazilian Zouk was developed in Rio de Janeiro in the mid 90s, and is now becoming more and more popular
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DfhRHnEAbak
..............
This is stunning to watch and even more fun to dance! It is based on the original Lambada dance but adapted to more modern music with a slow-quick-quick beat. It can be danced to a wide variety of music including R&B, Rock and Pop.
In this block of 5 classes you will discover the fundamental techniques, movements and sequences of Brazilian Zouk to get you up and running on the dance floor.
This includes:
Week 1: Passo basico
Week 2: Lateral
Week 3: Io-Io
Week 4: Bonus
Week 5: Combination
They are designed so you can start this block as a complete newbie, or you can continue on as an existing student from the last block.
There are 4 blocks of classes (A, B, C, D) in the complete Fundamentals course. Once these are done, you can progress to the Improvers classes.
Prices and payment:
- Prepaid 5 week term cost is $90 waged or $75 for unwaged/students.
- Ad hoc cost is $20 waged or $18 unwaged/students

description:
Cooking Classes, Authentic Indian cooking classes in Wellington with panaromic views over Wellington Harbour.

In each class, you will learn 4-5 recipes like: potato stuff roti, roasted eggplant curry, wholemeal, roti, naan; shahi paneer; dhal, samosa; palak paneer; gourmet chickpeas; vegetable korma; gulab jamun; kheer; mango lassi; masala chai, and many more...

The classes start at 6 pm or 10:30 am on weekends and weekdays with a 2-hour session followed by a dinner or lunch afterwards. The ingredients, copies of recipes, organic karma drink will be provided with a full course meal in a banquet setting. Custom made classes available for gluten free, dairy free and any other food intolerance and dietary requirements.The ingredients, recipes, complimentary organic karma drinks will be provided with a full course meal.

There are 2 to 8 people in each class in purpose built cooking studio. Also a private cooking classes available.

The menu for the class can be:

1) Spicy potato stuffed paratha and roti, rajasthani tomato relish, aalu matter or spicy peas- potato curry, roasted cumin yogurt raita and fresh mint- coriander chutney.

2) Shahi Paneer (cottage cheese cubes with spices and rich tomato-cashew gravy), garlic coriander naan, cumin jeera basmati rice and sweet fragrant rice pudding with cardamom. Also I will teach how to make fresh paneer.

3) Roasted eggplant curry, plain whole wheat chapatti or roti, jeera aaloo or potato curry, Tuar dahl (split yellow lentil) and Basmati rice with homemade pickle.

4) Palak paneer (creamy spinach curry with cubes of paneer), jeera rice (basmati rice with fragrant spices, panjabi chhole or spicy chickpeas curry and mango lassi. Also fresh paneer making.

5) Khadi (chickpeas fritters in yogurt and chickpeas flour soupy gravy), Aloo-Gobhi (cauliflower and potato curry),  savoury wraps with herbs and spices, fresh pickle and basmati rice.

The total cost is $130 per person, this includes ingredient cost. (As an alternative we also sell cooking class gift vouchers.The food options are unlimited and the class provides fresh and best ingredients)
For booking a class please contact indiancooking@xtra.co.nz

Just bring your taste buds! and Enjoy!!

description:
Spring Container Planting Workshop, Grow Your Own Kai - In Containers From Your Own Compost
Want to grow your own fresh kai but only have a balcony, patio, or courtyard? This hands-on workshop will show you how to grow spring vegetables and herbs in containers - a flexible, low-cost way to turn even the smallest space into a productive garden. Following on from our winter edition, this is the second workshop in our seasonal container growing series, with a focus on getting your spring garden thriving using your own compost.
This workshop will cover:
- What to grow in spring, including leafy greens, herbs, and root vegetables
- How to set up containers - choosing the right size, drainage, potting mix, and using your own compost or bokashi soil
- Feeding your plants with DIY fertilisers, spotting nutrient gaps, and refreshing tired soil
- Creating ideal growing conditions with sunlight, watering tips, wind protection, and natural pest control
- Keeping your garden productive by harvesting, replanting, and rotating crops throughout the season
Please bring your own container(s) - buckets, storage bins, flexi tubs, or old drawers all welcome. We will show you how to safely repurpose them.

description:
Monthly Life Drawing, Come along and have a go at portraiture with our koha life drawing sessions, hosted monthly at the Gallery.

With a mix of timed short and long poses, you are invited to bring your own materials or use the basic supplies we provide.

The sessions run from 2 pm to 4 pm—please arrive early to set up. We'll take a short kaputī break halfway through. This is a koha event, with all contributions going directly to our models. Friends and whānau are welcome!

Interested in modeling? Contact us—we're always looking for sitters. Everyone is welcome to join!

Accessibility Information: The New Zealand Portrait Gallery is an accessible venue, all on one level. There is an accessible wharepaku at the back of the venue. The gallery has automatic sliding doors and glass doors that can be pushed or pulled to enter. We have a wheelchair available for use within the gallery, and there is low stool seating throughout. If you have any questions regarding accessibility or if there is something we could do to make your visit easier, please get in touch.

description:
CHEERS DAD!, Come along for an afternoon creative session of painting a piece of pottery for Dad - or with Dad, whilst sipping on your choice of brew.
This is your opportunity to get sorted for Father's Day (Father's Day NZ is Sun 7th September).
Book a ticket for yourself, your family and your dad, enjoy a creative session altogether, each turning a mug or tumbler into work of Picasso. No family dramas just a fun old time.
If Dad can't make it, make him a custom gift. Bring along your partner or your beer loving bestie!
You will be guided through the process of painting (let's get our facts straight its actually underglaze not paint!) your Mug/Tumbler. Dad will treasure his custom made piece or you could make matching family mugs!
This Pottery painting workshop is absolutely suitable for anyone...even the least creative people!
Ticket price includes:




Your own ceramic Mug/Tumbler ready for decorating


One Beverage (Beer or non alcoholic)


All the materials needed


Guidance from me to create a piece Dad will treasure forever


1 Kiln firing ~ this makes the piece strong, shiny and food and drink safe
