description:
Secure Development Training - September 2025, Have you been to a Kawaiicon and found yourself realising that you want to know more? Are you a curious developer who wants to know what happens if you prod a web application? Are you a QA looking to take the worst path possible through an app?
Maybe the PrivSec Secure Development Training is for you!
Agenda
The training is a one day course consisting of the following:
A detailed overview of the OWASP Top Ten Web Application vulnerabilities.
Multiple real world examples and case studies of exploited vulnerabilities.
Hands on experience exploiting these vulnerabilities on a custom web application
Techniques and tooling to identify and exploit these bug classes, using both source code analysis and dynamic testing techniques.
Remediation steps and techniques to mitigate and avoid these issues.
Outcomes
By the end of the day, you will have an understanding of tools and techniques used to compromise web applications and hands on experience in exploiting multiple vulnerabilities in the OWASP top ten.
About the Trainer
Training will be led by one of our Senior consultants, Jack Moran and supported by Sriram Jayaraman
Jack is a Senior Consultant at PrivSec Consulting. He has worked in the offensive security space for the better part of a decade, focusing on web and mobile application testing, along with code reviews and security configuration reviews. He has a number of CVEs credited to himself, and his enthusiasm towards security security is infectious.
Sriram is an ex-developer, turned security consultant. He has a strong background in web application penetration testing, along with code review. He has familiarity with several programming and scripting languages and frameworks such as Python, Javascript, PHP, Node.js, Angular and React.
Notes for the Day
Lunch and snacks will be provided. We will teach you how to hack.

description:
What I Wish I Knew About Index Funds 5 Years Ago, People often ask me, “How do I best start investing?” It’s a great question—but not something I can explain in just a few minutes. That’s why I created this workshop.

This is a beginner-friendly, educational session focused on index fund investing—what it is, how it works, and how to actually get started. I’ll walk you through the full process: from understanding the basics to setting up your accounts, learning the key jargon, and knowing how to choose a fund that fits you.

We’ll cover important things like fees, tax, coverage, hedging, and more—things most people overlook when they first start. It’s not just theory. You’ll leave with a clear understanding of what to look for and how to take action confidently.

I’m not a financial adviser—this isn’t personal advice. It’s everything I wish someone had explained to me earlier. Because when you understand the process and use a simple strategy like dollar-cost averaging, you really can set yourself up for the long term.

If you’ve never invested before or just want to finally make sense of it all, this workshop is for you.

Through practical strategies, case studies, and interactive discussions, participants will learn how to develop a culture that motivates teams to excel, encourages open communication, and supports professional growth.

By the end of the course, participants will have the tools and insights needed to create a workplace environment that not only supports but accelerates the success of high-performing teams, driving both individual and collective achievement.

description: Inaugural Professorial Lecture - Professor Angela Ballantyne, Inaugural Professorial Lecture "Making things right". What does it mean to make things right? Medicine and science often turn to bioethics for concrete solutions to ethical challenges. But in reality, there is rarely a single, obvious ‘right’ answer. Human systems are inherently messy, and challenged by a legacy of injustice, unequal distributions of power, and declining social trust. This talk will describe the potential for bioethics to help clarify and navigate ethics dilemmas; pragmatically inching us closer to making things – if not right, then at least – better.

description:
Sir Ian Athfield Memorial Lecture 2025 | Te Whanganui-a-Tara Wellington, Te Kāhui Whaihanga New Zealand Institute of Architects are excited to welcome Ian Moore to New Zealand to present this year’s lecture series ‘The Past Needs a Future’ which will focus on adaptive reuse.
Ian is the principal of Ian Moore Architects, established in 1990. The practice has won numerous Australian and international awards and has been published and exhibited widely, including at the Venice Architecture Biennale in 2008 and 2012.
Initially studying civil and structural engineering at the Auckland Technical Institute in New Zealand, Ian moved on to study architecture at the University of Technology, Sydney, graduating with honours in 1988.
Ian has taught at numerous universities and been a speaker and guest lecturer throughout Australia as well as internationally.
Ian has also been a member of awards juries in Australia, New Zealand and at the World Festival of Interiors in 2013 and the World Architecture Festival in 2015. In 2003, Ian was the inaugural Creative Director for the Australian Institute of Architects annual conference.
About the Sir Ian Athfield Memorial Lecture
The annual Sir Ian Athfield Memorial Lecture commemorates the late Ian Athfield, a singular and much-loved figure in New Zealand architecture.
Affectionately known as ‘Ath’, Ian was knighted in 2014 and was one of New Zealand’s most influential architects. He won more than 60 national and international architecture and design awards and the lecture series was established to honour his legacy and celebrate his larrikin spirit.
In keeping with that spirit, each year the lecture is given by a person with something to say – someone who is challenging orthodoxy and a business-as-usual approach to practice, and life.
During his career, Ath designed many significant buildings, none more so than his own home in Te Whanganui-a-Tara Wellington, which enraged the neighbours, perplexed the Council and inspired the city for decades.
Ath was talented, original, insightful, opinionated, provocative, and sometimes outrageous. His architecture is stimulating, challenging, ever-changing, but never careless.
In 2004, Te Kāhui Whaihanga New Zealand Institute of Architects awarded Ath the Gold Medal for career achievements, noting at the time “What defines Athfield above all is his contagious enthusiasm, his devotion to architecture, and his unswerving belief in its possibilities. Believing architecture to be a civilising force, he has demonstrated a strong commitment to architecture’s public realm: the streets we live in; the urban centres we inhabit; the countryside we love and so often abuse.”
The Sir Ian Athfield Lecture Series is proudly sponsored by Resene and GIB.
CPD points: 10
TIMING:

Lecture: 5.30pm - 6.30pm
Q&A: 6.30pm - 7.00pm

description:
Site Visit - Holcim Readymix Wellington, Ever wondered how concrete is made?
Join us on Thursday 4th September, for an exclusive NAWIC members-only site tour of the Holcim Readymix NZ plant. Grab a behind the scenes look at:
 🏗️ The Process: How raw materials like cement, aggregates & water are mixed to create concrete
⚙️ Batching & Mixing: How mix designs are selected and adjusted
📏 Quality: Quality controls & production oversight, including testing & slumping
🚚 Dispatch:  Loading, scheduling & delivery coordination
🌱 Sustainability: Low carbon products and how Holcim is approaching driving a circular economy
 The Details:
🕒 DATE and TIME: Thursday, 4th September, 1pm
📍 LOCATION: 121 Centennial Highway, Ngauranga Gorge
🚗PARKING: Parking is tricky! Please carpool if possible, limited parking is available at the front of the Holcim offices (2 car parks) and one more at the top car park. Alternatively, bus route #1 stops off at Ngauranga Gorge (Kiwi Point) stop and is a short walk away
🎟️ COST: Free to NAWIC members, with a maximum of 10 people on the tour, so please book your space consciously. Get in quick! You can join NAWIC here.
👷‍♀️PPE: Hard hat, hi-vis, steel-capped boots, glasses (Spare hard-hats/hi-vis are available if required, please make sure you advise us of what you need on your RSVP.)
 ABOUT HOLCIM: Holcim is a global company across Europe, Asia, Pacific, Latin America, Middle East and Africa.  Holcim NZ  is a leading supplier of cement, aggregates and ready-mix concrete in New Zealand dating back to 1888. You may have noticed their big silos on the Centre Port (near the Interislander). Holcim have a network of plants throughout New Zealand, and one of their main missions is around sustainability, where they actively promote low-carbon concrete solutions, including their premium range ECOPact ECOplanet.
Please note: NAWIC is a voluntary organisation, committed to its obligations as a PCBU under the Health and Safety at Work Act 2015.   Amongst other things, this requires NAWIC to take all practicable steps to eliminate, isolate or minimize hazards that our event attendees are exposed to. Health and safety is a shared responsibility.

description:
Karanga taonga, karanga tangata, karanga whenua |Reversing Cultural Amnesia: Activating Māori Practice in Museums, In 1947, Māori leader, politician, and scholar Apirana Ngata spoke to his scholarly peers at the Polynesian Society, announcing his greatest desire to revive Māori culture as a living force within communities, not be relegated to dead exhibits in museums (Ramsden 1948, 85).
This lecture acknowledges the concerns of visionary leaders and champions of cultural practice and their activation within museums. Through her work as a Māori curator, writer, cultural practitioner and post-doctoral researcher, Awhina Tamarapa advocates for cultural restoration as a form of liberation in a museum context. In her research, Tamarapa is exploring strategies for the recovery and reclamation of taonga puoro (singing treasures) and karetao (animated storytellers) for new generations.
There are challenges regarding taonga held by overseas museums. Concepts such as keeping taonga warm, and mana taonga, recognises the connection and authority of descendants to their taonga, that underpin this work.
The focus on the reclamation of Indigenous practice has been bolstered by working with First Nations, Canada BC. Led by Professor Bryony Onciul, University of Exeter, UK, Tamarapa was privileged to be part of a research project “The Future of Indigenous Rights and Responsibilities: Ancestral governance, environmental stewardship, language revival, and cultural vibrancy” funded by the Arts and Humanities Research Council, UK.
_________
The Michael Volkerling Lecture series is a partnership event with the Museum and Heritage Studies programme at Te Herenga Waka | Victoria University of Wellington, National Services Te Paerangi and Te Papa Tongarewa. This annual public lecture series recognises the legacy of the late Dr Michael Volkerling who was one of the principal architects of New Zealand's cultural and creative sectors.

description:
Pride In Place: Creating a Community Walk Tour, Join the team from Walk Tours NZ for a free and inspiring presentation on how to create and run your own non-profit community walk tour.

Over the past seven years, Walk Tours NZ has delivered more than 100 community tours around central Wellington, focusing on the city’s rich LGBTQIA+ Rainbow heritage.

This event goes behind the scenes of creating a walk tour and is perfect for anyone passionate about bringing place-based history to light – whether it’s Rainbow histories or a topic of your own choosing.

Hosts Roger Smith and Gareth Watkins will guide you through the key ingredients of a successful non-profit walk tour – including identifying interesting stops, crafting compelling narratives, and being an engaging host – even if you’ve never done it before!

Bring your curiosity, enthusiasm and ideas, and discover why walk tours offer a unique form of living history – and how the experience can build community and connect people. No previous walk tour experience is necessary, and all are welcome.

The Queen Elizabeth II Pukeahu Education Centre (formerly the Home of Compassion Crèche) in Pukeahu Park has limited space, so registration is essential.
Please sign-up here: https://walktours.nz/book

This free community event is part of the Aotearoa Festival of Architecture 2025, organised by Walk Tours NZ in collaboration with the New Zealand Institute of Architects (Wellington Branch).

description:
Daffodil Express 2025, Carterton’s Daffodil Festival in the early Spring creates a great day out for the whole family. Why not travel there in style by a heritage train, let Steam Incorporated take the stress out of travel as you take the train to the Wairarapa. This year, our train has reduced capacity, so be sure to book in quickly!
Hauled by our heritage locomotives, take a glimpse into the bygone era of train travel as we clear the rush of Wellington, racing through the suburbs of Petone, Lower Hutt & Upper Hutt. After picking up the last of our passengers at Upper Hutt, we will race through the 8.8km long Rimutaka tunnel. This tunnel remains the longest in New Zealand with scheduled passenger trains, and has just been subjected to a full track relay for the first time since it was opened in 1955.
Passing through Featherston, we head east and navigate the rolling hills towards Carterton.
Arriving into Carterton, you'll have a few hours to disembark and go and explore Carterton's annual Daffodil Festival , before jumping on the train for the return journey home.
The Daffodil Fields and Festival
Located in the heart of the Wairarapa, Carterton’s popular Daffodil Festival offers an abundance of activities ranging from the famous Daffodil picking at Middlerun Farm, markets along High and Holloway Streets, the Big Wai Art sale in the events Centre, live music, and loads more family fun.
Shuttle buses will run from the town centre to the daffodil fields. There will be a lot of people for these buses, so please be patient. The bus transfer is free.
Here you can pick your own daffodils for $5 (Cash Preferred) that is a fundraiser for Wellington Free Ambulance and Whānau Āwhina Plunket, Wairarapa region. While stocks last!
The fields are not suitable for walkers or wheelchairs due to uneven grounds.
Prior booking is essential, this is an annual sell out event!
Fares
Adult (13+) - $125
Child (2-12yrs) - $90
Infant - Free
For more information & tickets, head to https://steaminc.org.nz/book-train-trip/daffodil-express/

description:
Water Cast Pendants Taster - Spring, This is a super quick 3-hour session, and is great fun to do with family or friends.

Water casting is a really hands-on low-tech casting method that results in surprising and fun little forms that can be turned into pendants with amazing textures and shapes.

You will be guided through melting silver and pouring it into water to create little charms.

Experiment with pouring at different heights to create different shapes.
Choose one or a few of your favourites to have drilled and turn into simple pendants or earrings, or new charms for your bracelets!

We will use hardened jump rings to attach your water-cast pieces to either colourful cord or you can choose sterling silver chains which you can purchase for extra.

The technique will be demonstrated with important health and safety practices, then students will be guided to do at least a couple of casts, and should expect to have at least one successful item to clean up and finish in the class.

A basic amount of metal allowance of a small amount of silver is included in your course costs, and if your projects go over that amount you can pay for the metal you use on the day via internet banking or cash.

This course is open to complete beginners and advanced makers. Extra materials such as chains and findings are available to purchase.

For health and safety reasons class participants must wear sturdy, closed toe shoes and have their hair tied back.

description:
Chess – Learn to Play, Chess is an ancient game of strategy and analysis that hones concentration and focus, as you master the skills allowing you to win at this competitive recreation.
Join tutor, Ryan Hill to learn how to play this game from the beginning.
You will quickly go from understanding the basics to being able to engage in playing confidently and discover where to go for further training or to carry on playing – both in person and online.
Over 600 million people play this game that has remained popular throughout the ages – why don’t you become one of them!
Bring pen and paper to take notes.
By the end of this course you will be able to:
*Be able to use all of the chess pieces to play the game
*Be able to recount and use some of the most common openings and traps
*Recognise where to go for further training or to play
*Develop increasing levels of confidence in your ability to play and possibly win
Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

description:
The Monster in the Maze, The myth of the Minotaur is a tale almost as old as storytelling itself, but with The Monster in the Maze Jonathan Dove and Alisdair Middleton have excavated rich, new life from this classic. In this brand new staging by director Anapela Polataivao (Red White and Brass, Wild Dogs Under My Skirt), this story will be told as never before.

When King Minos defeats the Athenians, he metes out his punishment in the cruellest way possible: by destroying their hope for the future. Every year, the king compels the conquered Athenians to send him their youth, to be fed to the terrible beast at the centre of his island’s maze: the Minotaur. As King Minos triumphs, his great monster “will eat your future, it will rip your hope, it will stamp your youth, your children in the sand.”

As the vindictive king will soon learn, however, these youth will not accept their fate without a fierce challenge. The Monster in the Maze is a story about resistance; about justice; about finding power not in oppression, but in collectivism. Fittingly, then, it’s also a groundbreaking work in its form: a community-focused and community-driven opera in which young and community singers and players stand proudly shoulder-to-shoulder with their professional counterparts, and in which both are integral.

The Monster in the Maze has been roundly praised by audiences, participants and reviewers worldwide, and in its Aotearoa debut season, it will serve as a gorgeous articulation of New Zealand Opera’s reciprocal community kaupapa.

Sung in English with surtitles.

description:
Kiwis Big Hararei, Written by Catriona Tipene & Ryan Cundy
Produced by Horse With No Name with GRIDLEY by Victoria
Directed by Catriona Tipene

From the Land of the Long White Cloud to the Land Down Under!

Kiwi is going on his first big holiday from Aotearoa across to the golden shores of Brisbane. He’s got his backpack, a pocket full of worms, and a head full of dreams. The most exciting thing of all is that he might even get to go on a rollercoaster! With his Mum, Kiwi navigates air travel, hotels and conversations with marsupials as his world stretches from the home he knows, to the world over the horizon.

A tale that celebrates the connection between our two countries, featuring stunning costume designs by GRIDLEY by Victoria and fresh waiata by NZ singer-songwriter Benny Tipene. Brought to the stage by the multi-award winning companies Horse With No Name and GRIDLEY by Victoria, Kiwi’s Big Hararei is a story about spreading your wings and flying into the unknown.

Acclaim for Trees, Bees and Me (2024):

“I don’t even know where to start in telling you how absolutely captivating, magical and real this show is.” Tania Du Toit, Regional News

“every costume adds such a beautiful connection between the characters while the colours each beautifully blend so well together.” Brie Keatley, Art Murmurs

Acclaim for Land of the Long Long Drive (2023):

“Horse With No Name have come up with one of the best children’s theatre shows that Wellington has seen in quite some time.” Deborah Rea, Theatreview

Tuesday 23 September 2025 to Saturday 4 October 2025
Tues – Sat 10.00am and 11.30am
Meet the cast: Wednesday 24th September 11.30am and Wednesday 1st October 11.30am

Glow Worm Tour Ticket Refund Policy
• No Refunds: We do not offer refunds for Glow Worm Tour tickets.
• Ticket Transfers: If you can’t attend your booked tour, we will put you on a future tour, subject to availability. Please contact us as soon as possible to arrange this.
• Weather Conditions: Tours operate rain or shine. In the event of extreme weather or unsafe conditions, we will reschedule your tour or provide a refund.

description:
Beervana, New Zealand’s boldest, hoppiest, and most delightfully weird beer festival. This is no ordinary tasting event, it’s a full-blown sensory adventure where brewers go wild, food gets fancy, and the unexpected is always on tap. 

Expect more than 60 breweries pouring over 300 unique brews—from hazy IPAs and fruited sours to beer cocktails and non-alcoholic surprises. 

But Beervana isn’t just about the beer. It’s a feast for all senses: think whitebait fritters from Boulcott St Bistro, Korean fried chicken, Mahurangi oysters. Add in live music, quirky brewery stands (yes, there’s a Best Stand vote), and unexpected entertainment and you’ve got a festival that you'll come away from with a greater knowledge of great beer, a belly full and plenty of fun memories with your mates.

description:
Wellington Home & Garden Show 2025, The entry ticket is non-refundable, but it is transferable so you if you can't attend for whatever reason, you can give the ticket to a friend.It’s all about ideas at the Wellington Home & Garden Show 2025. A wonderful range of exhibitors, 'Ask an Expert' sessions, latest trends, innovations and exclusive show specials it’s the place to be for inspiration for indoors and out.
For more information visit homeandgardenshow.co.nz or 'Like us' on Facebook.
We are working very hard to keep our events safe and we ask that you please stay home if you are unwell.
Show opening hours: Friday & Saturday 10-5pm, Sunday 10-4pm
FAQs
1. What are my transport/parking options for getting to and from the event?
Parking is available at the venue, at a cost of $10. Please note parking is card payment only (entry to the Show is card or cash).
2. What is the best time to attend?
Peak visitor times are normally between 11am - 2pm so the crowds are less outside of these times.
3. What days is the ticket valid for?
General Admission entry tickets is for one entry only and is valid for any one of the 3 event days.
Gold Card Special 1/2 price tickets valid for Friday only.
4. Do I have to bring my printed ticket to the event?
A printed ticket or showing the barcode on your phone to the entry staff is required.

description:
Wellington Jazz Festival, Soul, funk, jazz, fusion, rhythm and blues — it’s a celebration of sound across the city this spring. The annual Wellington Jazz Festival is back. The event packs over 100 gigs into five days in venues around the city. 
The festival features two major international acts making exclusive New Zealand debuts. Wellington will see two-time Grammy Award-winning jazz vocalist and bandleader, Gregory Porter and five-time Grammy Award-winning jazz singer, Samara Joy. Gregory Porter’s unique and timeless sound blends jazz, soul, and gospel. His influences include Bakersfield Southern Gospel and jazz legend Nat King Cole. At just 25 years old, Samara Joy has become a breakout jazz sensation. She’s redefining 21st-century jazz with a rich, mature tone and refined phrasing. 
The treats in the programme continue with Australian First Nations soul singer Bumpy, and a commissioned work by New Zealand/Congolese drummer, composer, and rhythm master  Myele Manzanza. He’ll be performing with international supergroup, lvdf. The Rodger Fox Big Band returns with a tribute to Ray Charles, and the Aotearoa Jazz Orchestra has its inaugural performance with a Duke Ellington arrangement of Tchaikovsky’s The Nutcracker Suite. Many of the hospitality venues in Courtenay Place and its surrounding streets are planning intimate jazz gigs across the festival. Follow the sound of saxophones to find a spot to park up for the night.

This group will be heading into town by 8:15am and with an action-packed day planned, will stay in town until their 5pm performance.
Following the show, our students will be ready to head home with their spectator parents. Watch this space for more details and how you can help.
In the meantime, follow the link to book tickets on the Ticketmaster website– don’t miss out!

description:

Mrs Long and Mr Graff have a hard-working troupe of dancers training to perform on Thursday 28 August at the 5pm show, held at the Opera House.
This is a new venue for the show, what a treat! This group will be heading into town by 8:15am for the dress rehearsal, before returning to school to catch their breath. They’ll head back in together on the bus and will be ready to head home with their spectator parents at the conclusion of the show. Watch this space for more details and how you can help.

description:
Te Wā o Te Kōanga - Spring Festival, Te Wā o te Kōanga | Spring Festival 2025
It’s time to shake off the winter blues and celebrate kōanga/spring at Wellington Gardens!

Join us throughout September for Te Wā o te Kōanga, a month-long festival bursting with flowers, fresh beginnings, and lots of ways to connect with nature and community.
Explore both Wellington Botanic Garden ki Paekākā and Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush with events for everyone — from self-drive floral tours and roaming performers, to interactive family fun, art exhibitions, and behind-the-scenes experiences.

Bring your friends, whānau, and neighbours to celebrate the season of new life in Aotearoa’s special native and cultivated gardens.
Stay tuned for event highlights and come discover the joy of kōanga!

description:
Wellington Spring Festival – Government House Garden tour, As part of Wellington's Spring Fetival, explore Government House gardens with the BARK garden team (90 minute tour)

Government House was opened in Newtown in 1910, and its extensive gardens have been in continuous development since then. As part of the Spring Festival, the Government House garden team is offering guided walks through our gardens. Tours will go ahead regardless of weather. Tours will not enter the main house.

Bookings are essential for the free tour. Places are limited: https://gg.govt.nz/government-house/government-house-wellington/government-house-tours/upcoming

Some parts of our grounds are not mobility friendly. Please contact the Visitor Centre direct if you have any questions regarding accessibility.

Groups wanting to organise a garden tour or house tour can email our Visitor Centre team direct: bookings@govthouse.govt.nz

If you have any questions or need more information, please email us at bookings@govthouse.govt.nz, or call us at 04-382-0837. You will receive a reminder email 24 hours before your tour.

description:
Omaka Wings & Wheels 28th Sept, Daylight Savings is coming, and so is the Omaka Aviation Heritage Centre's Wings & Wheels Open Day! Make sure to mark Sunday, 28th September, 2025, on your calendar to spring forward into an amazing day of aircraft and classic cars!

We have a spectacular lineup of aircraft planned from throughout history, and joy flights will be available. Re-hydrate and refuel at the Omaka Cafe and guest food outlets. Bring your picnic rugs and deck chairs, and make yourself comfortable because you won't want to leave!

And don't forget to take the opportunity to visit the two remarkable exhibitions at the Omaka Aviation Heritage Centre. Entry to both is included in your Omaka Wings & Wheels ticket. For value for money, it doesn't get any better than this!
** There will be gate sales on the day. However, we highly recommend that you pre-purchase tickets online for the best price and quickest check-in experience. **

With WOW's internationally acclaimed creative team at the helm, don't miss this unforgettable spectacle of boundless imagination and jaw-dropping artistry.

description:
Martinborough Music Festival 2025, Bringing the world to Martinborough for chamber music in the heart of South Wairarapa.

Join us for four exciting concerts over three days, featuring stunning New Zealand and international artists including Natalia Lomeiko (violin), Yuri Zhislin (violin/viola), Matthias Balzat and Ashley Brown (cello), Jian Liu (piano), Wilma Smith and Donald Armstrong (violin), Simon Brew (saxophone) and Caroline Henbest (viola).

These artists will bring to life extraordinary works including Zoltán Kodály's Duo for Violin and Cello, Op. 7; JS Bach's Goldberg Variations for string trio; Shostakovich's Piano Quintet in G minor, Op. 57 and Mozart's String Quintet No. 5 in D major, K.593.

The Sunday afternoon concert will also include the world premiere of Shifting Worlds, a piano quintet by renowned New Zealand composer Louise Webster, who has special ties with South Wairarapa.

Visit martinboroughmusicfestival.co.nz for more information about artists, programmes and links to ticket sales.

description:
Great Sounds Great Festival 2025, Eyegum Music Collective presents GREAT SOUNDS GREAT, a multi-venue music and arts festival taking over Pōneke's Cuba Street precinct for one night only on Saturday 6 September 2025. Showcasing 40 of Aotearoa's best artists across 10 neighbouring venues, this is one big party you shouldn't miss.

Eyegum has worked hard to curate a programme that is sure to offer something for everyone, from first time gig-goers to seasoned live music obsessives. The eclectic lineup includes perennial indie maestros The Bats, capital hometown heroes The Phoenix Foundation, hip hop superstar JessB, troubadour-turned-party starter Anthonie Tonnon, captivating genre-bender Reb Fountain, the incredible local-by-way-of-Naarm Jen Cloher, plus a selection of up-and-coming artists handpicked from Eyegum's Free Wednesday weekly showcase series, and everything in between. There will also be plenty more to be announced soon.

Excitingly for 2025, we will be adding three new venues: St Peter's on Willis, Flying Nun Records and 13 Garrett Street (sponsored by Radio Active), as well as a travelling electronic stage curated by Tonic Collective. This means more artists and music to experience in a variety of special and unique spaces throughout the night.

Ticket holders will receive a wristband that will give them access to each of the participating venues throughout the event. Information on how to pick up wristbands will be provided to ticket holders closer to the time.

Tickets are on sale now at eyegum.co.nz/great-sounds-great

When: from 4pm Saturday 6 September 2025
Where: San Fran, Meow, Valhalla, Rogue & Vagabond, Bedlam & Squalor, Hotel Bristol (2 stages), St Peter's on Willis, Flying Nun Records, 13 Garrett St

Who: The lineup will include Anthonie Tonnon, Baby Zionov, Bad Taste, BADTAB, Baeoli, Bathysphere, The Bats, By A Damn Sight, Cindy, Eveline Breaker, Goya, Half/Angel, Hans Pucket, Iris Little, Jazmine Mary, Jen Cloher, JessB, JHL, Jim Nothing, Jordan Hamel, Leah Dodd, LEAO, Louisa Nicklin, The Phoenix Foundation, Reb Fountain, Rebecca Hawkes, Shayne P Carter (solo), Sig Wilder & Friends, Sofia Machray, Space Bats, Attack!, The Spectre Collective: live-scored cinema, Star Time, plus more artists to be announced soon.

description:
Jenin Jenin Screening, This spring from the 28th of August to the 2nd of October we will be screening a series of excellent Palestinian films, old and new, every week at two/fiftyseven on Willis Street, with ticket sales going to the Gazan mutual aid group The Sameer Project.
The Sameer Project is an on-the-ground aid organisation organised by Palestinians in the diaspora, which crowdfunds in order to provide tents, medical care and direct cash aid to those most affected in Gaza. They can be found on Instagram at @thesameerproject.
More information:
Jenin Jenin includes testimony from Jenin residents after the Israeli army’s Defensive Shield operation, during which the city and camp were the scenes of fierce fighting. The operation ended with Jenin flattened and scores of Palestinians killed. Palestinians as well as numerous human rights groups accused Israel of committing war crimes in the April 2002 attack on the refugee camp. The sad question forces itself on the spectator: What will become of a country, a people when its children are confronted with war and violence from a very early age?

description:
Wairarapa Word - Lifeswap, Come and hear the makers of NZ's favourite cross-cultural animated comedy series Lifeswap speak and watch all episodes on the big screen.
Created by Wairarapa-based writer William Connor and animator Steffen Kreft.
The Wairarapa debut of all 15 episodes.
Presented by Wairarapa Word.
Tickets $10

Steffen Kreft is an animation film director, illustrator, marionette maker and puppeteer. William Connor is a writer, translator, editor, teacher, and puppeteer. Steffen was born in Germany, and William in Aotearoa. They currently live in Greytown.

William and Steffen will also lead a stop-motion animation workshop on Sunday 7 September, 1-6pm. For ages 12+. Free of charge. Places are limited. Participants will need to download an app on their smartphone and bring along a desk lamp. Supported by Wairarapa Library Service. To register your interest, please email .

description:
🎬 Movie Fundraiser: Kneecap 🎬, This time last year, Kneecap premiered at the Wellington Film Festival - but not enough people got to see it. Some films deserve the big screen experience, so I’m bringing it back!
Come along for a movie night with a twist - supporting a great cause while enjoying this epic film. Set in Belfast, this wild, witty, and politically charged story follows the rise of the real-life rap trio Kneecap, blending music, humour, and rebellion in a way only the Irish can.
Your ticket includes the screening plus a raffle with a twist 😉 - and every dollar goes towards my campaign, helping cover those last few expenses. Imagine the good we can do for our communities when I’m elected!
📅 Date: Monday 8 September
🕖 Time: 5.45pm
Location: Lighthouse Cinema Cuba Street
It’s a perfect chance to laugh and cry - imagine Derry Girls, Trainspotting and Spinal Tap combined - it will change you for the better and help make a difference - so gather your mates and join us for some great craic!

description:
Rongotai Labour Film Evening, For everyone who missed the showing of "Prime Minister' - a film about the extraordinary term of Jacinda Adern's leadership of New Zealand - at the NZIFF, Rongotai Labour is pleased to secure a showing to help to raise funds for the 2026 election campaign.
This film chronicles Jacinda Adern's tenure as Prime Minister and provides an insight into both the political and personal challenges Jacinda faced during those six years. The inclusion of considerable footage from Jacinda's partner Clarke Gayford provides a deeply personal view of life as the Prime Minister in very challenging times.
(Los Angeles Times review) 'Prime Minister' is not interested in wrangling, dealing and lawmaking, or even the nuts and bolts or her progressive views. .. But in the fleet, pacey manner of the editing, toggling between private and public moments with highlight-reel efficiency, the film is a stirring glimpse of top-down kindness as a winning leadership style.

description:
Seen The Film - Wellington, NZ. A Fundraiser for Te Aro School., 🎥 Seen The Film- Wellington Screening- a Fundraiser for Te Aro School 🎥
When: Sunday, 7th September 2025
Time: 4pm until 5:30pm
Where: Vogelmorn Bowling Club UPSTAIRS, 93 Mornington Road, Wellington.
This is a fundraising event for an outdoor learning space for Te Aro School children.
Be part of an inspiring and thought-provoking morning as we screen SEEN: The Film, a powerful documentary exploring the long-term impact of childhood trauma and the journey of healing to create stronger, healthier families.
Tickets: Reserve your seat now – spaces are limited!
📍 Don’t miss this chance to join the conversation and the movement to create a brighter future for children and families.
Grab your ticket today and help us create change, one story at a time.
label: Film & Media

description:
Jina (Mahsa) Amini's Third Anniversary - Movie Screening: Reading Lolita in Tehran, On 16 September 2022, Jina (Mahsa) Amini was killed in state custody after her arrest by Islamic Republic's morality police, sparking the Woman, Life, Freedom movement.
Join us for a free community screening to mark the third anniversary of Jina Amini. The Iranian Solidarity Group NZ will screen Reading Lolita in Tehran — a 2024 feature film exploring courage, literature, and resistance in Iran.
Event Details:
• Date: Saturday, 13 September 2025
• Time: Doors open 3:45 pm· Programme begins 4:00 pm· Film starts 4:30 pm (sharp).
• Venue: two/fiftyseven Community Centre
• Address: 2/57 Willis Street, Wellington (Entry via 70 Victoria Street)
• Ticket fee: Free
• Film: Reading Lolita in Tehran (feature, approx. 108 minutes)
• Light refreshments will be provided.
 Note: 
We have a one-off online streaming permission for the film. In case of any internet outage on the day, we will screen Parastoo Ahmadi’s Karvansara concert and a previously held panel discussion on "Woman, Life, Freedom: Pathways to Justice.”
label: Film & Media

description:
Puck Lane Creative Workshop - Woodblock Artwork with Mixed Media, Puck Lane Creative Workshops
Puck Lane Creative Workshops
Woodblock Artwork + Mixed Media
In collaboration with Treacle Lane and House of Puck, we invite you to a super fun evening of creative chaos—in the best possible way.
This workshop? We're building bold, beautiful mixed media artwork with woodblocks, nails, thread, and collage. It’s part art, part alchemy—all materials included, no stress required.
Just book your spot, show up, and let your inner maker run wild. The space is ambient, the vibes are high, and the snacks are not messing around. Sip something nice, hammer something gently, and create something you didn’t know you had in you.
label: Film & Media

description:
Terror-Fi Presents: THE TOXIC AVENGER (NZ Premiere - Wellington), Be the first in New Zealand to see THE TOXIC AVENGER, starring Peter Dinklage, Kevin Bacon, and our favourite adopted Kiwi Elijah Wood.
Comically violent, absurdly gory, and extremely entertaining ... Toxie is the radioactive antidote to superhero fatigue. 92% on Rotten Tomatoes and not to be missed on the big screen – especially as it almost didn’t make it to our cinemas!
“When a downtrodden janitor, Winston Gooze, is exposed to a catastrophic toxic accident, he’s transformed into a new kind of hero: The Toxic Avenger. Now, Toxie must rise from outcast to saviour, taking on ruthless corporate overlords and corrupt forces who threaten his son, his friends, and his community. In a world where greed runs rampant … justice is best served radioactive.”
label: Film & Media

description:
Perfect Days, Come along to our free Japanese Film night, co-organised with the Japan Foundation, Sydney!

Synopsis
Hirayama seems utterly content with his simple life as a cleaner of toilets in Tokyo. Outside of his very structured everyday routine he enjoys his passion for music and for books. And he loves trees and takes photos of them. A series of unexpected encounters gradually reveal more of his past. A deeply moving and poetic reflection on finding beauty in the everyday world around us.
Director: Wim Wenders / Classification: M / Year: 2023 / Genre: Drama
Language: Japanese with English subtitles

Copyright:© 2023 Master Mind Ltd.

A short Japan Video Topics DVD will be shown from 5:15pm before the start of the film at 5:30pm. Free admission is based on a first-come, first-served basis, with a full theatre capacity of 40 people. No food is permitted in the theatre

description:
Twin Peaks Meetup Wellington: Season 2 - Episodes 8 & 9, If the sound of watching Twin Peaks together with a bunch of like minded fans sounds like a good idea, then you've come to the right place!

Last time we met we celebrated completing all of Season 1 together.

I am excited to announce we are now going to watch Season 2! Starting off with the special double length "Episode 8: May the Giant Be With You". Written by Mark Frost, David Lynch and directed by David Lynch. Followed by "Episode 9:Coma". Directed by David Lynch.

This is what we will be watching :

-Short Recap "Previously...on Twin Peaks"

-Episode 8: "May the Giant Be With You" (93mins)

-Intermission

-Episode 9: "Coma" (46mins)

With all Log Lady Intros!

WHERE: The mini cinema in Te Auaha. 65 Dixon St. Te Aro.

(Take the lift or stairs to Level 1 and turn left.)
The mini cinema's specs: 4K projection, Screen size 4450mm x 2500mm, Aspect ratio 16:9 with 7.1 surround sound.

Here is a link to Te Auaha's cinema so you know what to expect.
https://www.teauahaevents.com/our-spaces/cinema

WHEN: Meet at 10:30am on Saturday 6th Sept. 2025. in the Bar area. The bar will be closed but you are welcome to bring your own snacks/drink.

Chat with other Twin peakies and the show will start on the dot at 11:00am

COST: Tickets are $10 per person

Tickets will be capped/limited so that everyone can have a decent seat. Every single screening so far has sold out well in advance, so grab those tickets ASAP and don't miss out on experiencing the epic start to Season 2 in a room full of your people that love Twin Peaks!


RULES:
1. Tickets are per person. There will be NO door sales, so DO purchase it beforehand please.

2. All attendees MUST be 18yo +

3. This is a safe, friendly, INCLUSIVE place. There is ZERO tolerance for discrimination, disrespect or creepy gross behavior of any kind. By attending you agree to the Code of Conduct.

4. Please clean up after yourself if you are snacking and help keep the mini cinema clean as a whistle.

Thank you! And hope to see you there.

description:
Wellington Timebank fundraiser screening of Tinā, Get your tickets here - https://events.humanitix.com/wtb-fundraiser-screening-of...
Join us for this special screening of this award winning Aotearoa-made film - Tinā (2024). If you missed it in the cinemas the first time round, you can now watch it from the comfort of the Newtown Community Centre!
Doors open at 5pm
Film starts at 6pm (running time is 2 hours 4 minutes)
Tickets are just $25 waged / $20 unwaged (all tickets include snacks) and proceeds go toward keeping your Timebank in operation.
About the film:
Award-winning writer/director Miki Magasiva (The Panthers, We Are Still Here) makes his feature debut with Tinā (Samoan for "mother"). Samoan music teacher Mareta (Anapela Polataivao) is plunged into grief after losing her daughter in the Christchurch quakes. Mareta takes a relieving role at an elite private school, where she inspires her students to perform at a big choral competition. In the trailer Mareta faces a condescending interview at Saint Francis, and her growing relationship with "spoiled, rich kids" annoys a family member. Tinā was chosen to open the 2024 Hawai’i International Film Festival.
label: Film & Media

description:
Film screening: GAGA, Gaga《哈勇家》(2022)
Directed by Laha Mebow 112 mins, Mandarin/Atayal/Taiwanese, English subtitles
Among the Atayal indigenous people of Taiwan, gaga is the traditional law and custom, the way of living with the land and organising society, the source of values. When Hayung, the patriarch of an Atayal family, and the senior knowledge-keeper, dies, his oldest son Payang decides to run for election as head of the local district. The film Gaga follows this election, in its raw democratic, and occasionally corrupt, form and the ways – sometimes serious, sometimes hilarious – that it affects the extended family. A groundbreaking film, Gaga is mostly in Atayal language and presents the life and social interactions of these contemporary indigenous Taiwanese people unsentimentally, with humour, with compassion, and with the sharp eye of a brilliant film-maker.
Gaga won Best Director and Best Supporting Actress at the 59th Taipei Golden Horse Film Festival in 2022. Beyond Taiwan, it won the Best Director at the 2022 Singapore International Film Festival - Asian Feature Competition and has been screened at film festivals in Hawaii, Los Angeles, Melbourne, Auckland and New York.
Q&A with Film Director Laha Mebow
We are delighted that Film Director Laha Mebow, Taiwan's first indigenous female director, will be attending the screening and take part in Q&A afterwards.
Laha Mebow is the first female director from Taiwan to win Best Director at the Golden Horse Awards, the most prestigious film award in the Chinese-speaking world. An Indigenous filmmaker of the Tayal people, she is also the first Indigenous woman in Taiwan to direct a narrative feature. Her films explore spiritual inheritance, family trauma, and Indigenous identity through a deeply personal yet cinematic lens.
She has directed three feature films. Finding Sayun (2011) reimagines a colonial-era legend from an Indigenous perspective. Lokah Laqi! (2016), a coming-of-age tale of three Indigenous boys, was selected as Taiwan’s official submission for Best Foreign Language Film at the Academy Awards. Her third feature, Gaga (2022), won Best Film at the Singapore International Film Festival and delves into generational shifts and cultural survival within an Indigenous family.
Laha’s body of work continues to break new ground for Indigenous representation in Asian cinema. Her unique voice bridges traditional storytelling and contemporary filmmaking, making her one of the most important and anticipated directors from Taiwan today.
label: Film & Media

description:
French Film Screening - Chien de la Casse, 🎬 Join us for a screening of Chien de la casse (Junkyard Dog) - a gritty and quietly powerful French drama exploring friendship, masculinity, and emotional repression in a small town in France.
The plot 👉 In a sleepy village in the South of France, Dog and Mirales have been inseparable since childhood. Their bond is strong but also marked by teasing and power games - until a new arrival, Elsa, disrupts the dynamic. As Dog starts to drift toward this budding romance, Mirales is left grappling with jealousy, vulnerability, and the fear of being left behind.
The trailer 👉 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tCv83D3CQOY
Chien de la casse is a nuanced and touching debut feature by Jean-Baptiste Durand - a subtle portrait of male friendship, emotional fragility, and the unspoken tensions of rural life.
This film is rated R13 – Restricted to persons 13 years and over (Violence, offensive language, drug use & sex scenes).
📅 Friday, 05 September 2025 - 6pm
📍 Alliance Française, 78 Victoria Street, Wellington
🎥 French VO with English Subtitles
🎟️ Free entry, Koha donation

Strap in for a thrilling night of unparalleled talent from local filmmakers from your area. Be prepared for a joyride of emotions and a whole lot of fun.

Following the screenings, we'll honour the filmmakers with prestigious awards.

description:
Halloween Film Night 2025, Film Talks Presents: Halloween Film Night 2025
Get ready for a night of cinematic chills and festive frights! Since 2022, Film Talks’ Halloween Film Night has brought Wairarapa audiences together to explore classic horror films in a fun, immersive atmosphere. Over the past three years, we’ve journeyed through the shadows of 1920s German Expressionist cinema, and this year we step into 1930s Hollywood Gothic Horror with Universal Pictures’ The Bride of Frankenstein (1935)—a Gothic horror classic with unforgettable visuals, thrilling storytelling, and timeless appeal.
Doors open at 6:45 pm, and the movie begins at 7 pm at Aratoi, 12 Bruce Street, Masterton. Running time: 75 minutes.
Costumes are encouraged, with spot prizes for the best dressed, making it a night that’s as much about fun and community as it is about film. Perfect for families, friends, and cinephiles, the event promises shared laughs, playful scares, and a celebration of classic cinema. The film is not rated but recommended for ages 9+.
Book tickets to reserve your seat. Koha welcome: suggested $5. Your contribution helps support the event and keep Film Talks experiences running for the community.
Presented by Film Talks, in association with the Wellington Heritage Festival. This is an evening you won’t want to miss!
label: Film & Media

Date & Time: Thursday, 28 August 2025 – Time: 5:30 PM
Venue: Embassy of Japan, 100 Willis St, Wellington, Rating : M
Free admission
copyright:© 2023 Master Mind Ltd.
Hirayama seems utterly content with his simple life as a toilet cleaner in Tokyo.
Outside his structured daily routine, he enjoys music, books, and photographing trees he loves.
A series of unexpected encounters gradually reveal more about his past. A deeply moving and poetic film about finding beauty in the everyday world around us.

description:
Sing Sing Film Fundraiser - Arts in Corrections Network, Join Arts Access Aotearoa for a powerful evening of film and purpose as we screen the critically acclaimed movie Sing Sing — based on a true story of redemption, creativity and the transformative power of the arts within the prison system.
Sing Sing tells the story of incarcerated men who find hope and humanity through a prison theatre programme. It reflects the values Arts Access Aotearoa upholds: that the arts can break down walls, build confidence and create change, inside and out.
Tickets are $25 and proceeds support the Arts in Corrections Network.
Before the screening, you will hear from actor, playwright and musician Jamie McCaskill (of the Māori Sidesteps musical comedy group), and playwright and columnist Dave Armstrong. Together, they led a powerful theatre and storytelling course at Whanganui Prison, supporting and transformation behind the wire.
Come along and support us to continue this important work.
About Arts in Corrections
Arts programmes in prisons can be powerful pathways to healing and change. They help people restore their sense of identity, build resilience and develop skills that support rehabilitation and reintegration into the community. By nurturing creative potential and cultural identity these programmes foster personal transformation.
Arts Access Aotearoa leads a national network that supports Corrections staff and community educators and groups to design and deliver meaningful arts programmes in prisons and Community Corrections..
label: Film & Media

description:
Textiles and Queerness in a NZ Film! Went Up The Hill at NZIFF Wellington, Hi queer friends who love crafts-have I got the film for you! NZ feature film Went Up The Hill will have its Wellington Premiere at the NZ International Film Festival on 21 August at the Embassy at 830pm-get your ticket now!
Come along and be amongst the first to see NZ feature film Went Up The Hill from queer NZ filmmaker Sam Van Grinsven.
Tickets to the Wellington screening are available for $26 at the NZIFF website:
https://www.nziff.co.nz/.../te.../went-up-the-hill/
The film is also screening at NZIFF in centres around the country including Auckland, Christchurch, Dunedin amongst others!
Shot in Canterbury and funded by the NZ Film Commission, the film stars Vicky Krieps (The Phantom Thread) and Dacre Montgomery (Stranger Things) in a poetic ghost story that centres on two queer characters-a woman and her dead wife’s estranged son -as they are each haunted by her spirit. The film premiered to critical acclaim as a Special Presentation at Toronto Film Festival in 2024 where Sam was hailed by Hollywood Reporter as already having the ‘control of a master’ in a film that is ‘captivating', ‘elliptical' and 'technically stunning’.
Sam Van Grinsven has a passion for queer interpretation of genre and seeing queer characters within spaces that historically have not been explored as diversely.
Here's the trailer link-we hope you can join us!
label: Film & Media

description:
The Kava Experience, Bula Vinaka and Welcome to Kava Culture, New Zealand’s newest destination for authentic Fijian Kava!
We are thrilled to invite you to another relaxing Kava Experience night. Whether you're a curious newcomer or a seasoned kava enthusiast, our dedicated team will warmly guide you through every step of this unique journey.
At Kava Culture, we offer a premium, traditionally brewed kava experience designed for wellness-focused individuals seeking natural relaxation. We pride ourselves on sourcing our kava directly from small Pacific Island farms, ensuring unparalleled quality and authenticity.
Immerse yourself in the rich traditions of the Pacific as you enjoy our exquisite kava in our calm, serene location at Kaitahi, beautifully illuminated by ambient lights. This is more than just a drink; it's an opportunity to connect with others, promote genuine stress relief, and celebrate ancient island culture with modern comfort.
Join us for a night filled with community, connection, and tranquility. Let Kava Culture transport you – no passport required!
Choose your journey:
* Mini Experience: $30 (1.5 hours)
* Full Experience: $50 (3 hours)
We can’t wait to welcome you!
